European Commission

Sinopec Chongqing SVW Chemical Co. Ltd, Sinopec Great Wall Energy & Chemical (Ningxia) Co. Ltd, Central-China Company, Sinopec Chemical Commercial Holding Co. Ltd

( Appeal – Dumping – Imports of certain polyvinyl alcohols originating from China – Definitive anti-dumping duty – Implementing Regulation (EU) 2020/1336 – Non-Cooperation – Article 18(1) and (6) of Regulation (EU) 2016/1036 – Fair comparison at the same level of trade – Construction of the normal value in case of significant distortions in the exporting country – Article 2(6a) and (10) of Regulation 2016/1036 – Adjustments – Single economic entity – Article 2(10)(i) of Regulation 2016/1036 – Non-refundable VAT – Article 2(10)(k) of Regulation 2016/1036 )

I. Introduction

• 1. The present case raises significant issues concerning the European Commission's anti-dumping investigations.
  • 2. This is the first case in which the Court of Justice is called upon to interpret the application of the new methodology laid down in Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation, (2) which is used to construct the normal value in cases of exports from countries whose domestic market is subject to significant distortions. The Court's judgment will have far-reaching implications for the Commission's future handling of investigations applying that methodology. The present case also gives the Court the opportunity to further clarify the scope of the Commission's discretion when using facts available, in accordance with Article 18 of the basic Regulation, in cases of lack of cooperation of interested parties, as well as the scope of adjustments under Article 2(10)(i) and (k) of the basic Regulation.
  • 3. The case concerns an appeal lodged by the Commission and a cross-appeal lodged by three companies of the Sinopec Group, (3) one of the largest Chinese corporate groups, which were applicants at first instance. The appeal and the crossappeal concern a judgment of the General Court of the European Union (4) ('the judgment under appeal') by which that Court annulled a Commission implementing regulation imposing definitive anti-dumping duties on imports of certain polyvinyl alcohols originating in the People's Republic of China (5) ('the regulation at issue').
  • 4. In essence, by the regulation at issue, the Commission imposed, inter alia, a definitive anti-dumping duty of 17.3% on
imports of certain PVA products of Sinopec.

• 5. Having found that there were 'significant distortions' in China, (6) the Commission constructed the normal value in accordance with the methodology laid down in Article 2(6a)(a) of the basic Regulation, (7) including what it considered to be an undistorted and reasonable amount for selling, general and administrative costs ('SG&A costs') and for profits. (8)
  • 6. In that context, first, as regards Sinopec Ningxia, the Commission identified some serious deficiencies in the data provided in respect of its production costs. Accordingly, when constructing the normal value for that company the Commission used the 'facts available' in accordance with Article 18(1) of the basic Regulation. (9) The Commission decided, for each type of product concerned, to use the highest of the constructed normal values of the other cooperating exporting producers. (10)
  • 7. Second, the Commission made downward adjustments to the export price, deducting insurance costs, transport, handling and loading expenses, credit costs and bank charges ('the costs at issue'). (11)Third, the Commission made a downward adjustment to the export price under Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation. (12)Fourth, the Commission made an upward adjustment to the normal value under Article 2(10)(b) of the basic Regulation. (13)
  • 8. In the judgment under appeal, the General Court, first, found that the Commission had infringed Article 18 of the basic Regulation in so far as it had calculated Sinopec Ningxia's normal value by using, for each product type, the highest of the normal values of the other exporting producers. (14)Second, the General Court found that the Commission had infringed its obligation under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation to make a fair comparison at the same level of trade between the export price and the normal value, in so far as the Commission had deducted 'the costs at issue' from the export price. The General Court also found that the Commission had infringed the principle of good administration by requiring Sinopec to adduce unreasonable proof. (15)Third, the General Court found that the Commission had infringed Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation in so far as it had found that the functions of Sinopec Central-China were similar to those of an agent working on a commission basis. (16)
  • 9. The General Court therefore annulled the regulation at issue with regard to Sinopec in so far as the Commission had committed the abovementioned infringements. The remainder of the action was dismissed.
  • 10. The Commission and Sinopec lodged, respectively, an appeal and a cross-appeal before the Court.
II. The appeal

• 11. By its appeal, the Commission, supported by Kuraray Europe GmbH ('Kuraray'), intervener at first instance, asks the Court to set aside the judgment under appeal and order Sinopec to pay the costs of the first instance and appeal proceedings.
  • 12. Sinopec, supported by Wegochem Europe BV ('Wegochem'), intervener at first instance, asks the Court, in essence, to dismiss the appeal and, in the alternative, to refer the case back to the General Court for reconsideration and order the Commission to bear the costs.
  • 13. In support of its appeal, the Commission relies on three grounds of appeal, by which it submits that the General Court erred in finding each of the infringements mentioned in point 8 of the present Opinion.
A. The first ground of appeal, relating to the infringement of Article 18 of the basic Regulation

• 14. The first ground of appeal of the Commission concerns the General Court's findings in paragraphs 211 to 221 of the judgment under appeal. In those paragraphs the General Court upheld the plea by which Sinopec argued that the Commission had infringed Article 18 of the basic Regulation.
  • 15. The relevant provisions of Article 18 of the basic Regulation are worded as follows:
  • '1. In cases in which any interested party refuses access to, or otherwise does not provide, necessary information within the time limits provided for in this Regulation, or significantly impedes the investigation, provisional or final findings, affirmative or negative, may be made on the basis of the facts available.

5. If determinations, including those regarding normal value, are based on the provisions of paragraph 1, including the information supplied in the complaint, it shall, where practicable and with due regard to the time limits of the investigation, be checked by reference to information from other independent sources which may be available, such as published price lists, official import statistics and customs returns, or information obtained from other interested parties during the investigation.
…

6. If an interested party does not cooperate, or cooperates only partially, so that relevant information is thereby withheld, the result of the investigation may be less favourable to the party than if it had cooperated.'
1. Background to the disputed issue

• 16. In recitals 327 to 329 of the regulation at issue, after identifying serious deficiencies in the reporting of the cost of production relating to Sinopec Ningxia, the Commission decided to apply 'facts available' in accordance with Article 18 of the basic Regulation as far as the calculation of the normal value of that company was concerned. Thus, the normal value for that company was constructed, under Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation, using the information provided by the other cooperating exporting producers. In particular, for each product type reported by that company, the Commission used the highest constructed normal value of the other cooperating exporting producers.
  • 17. In recital 333 of the regulation at issue the Commission rejected the claims that that approach was punitive. The Commission considered that since it 'was unable to verify and therefore use the data supplied by Sinopec Ningxia for the construction of its normal value, there [was] no evidence suggesting that Sinopec Ningxia's normal value per product type would be below the highest normal value per product type of the other cooperating producers that use similar raw materials'.
  • 18. In the judgment under appeal the General Court considered that the Commission had, in the regulation at issue, applied a presumption that Sinopec Ningxia's normal value, per product type, was not below the highest of the normal values of the other cooperating exporting producers. The General Court found that it was not the intention of the EU legislature to establish, under Article 18 of the basic Regulation, such a legal presumption, exempting the EU institutions from any requirement to adduce proof. The General Court observed that the Commission had acknowledged during the hearing before that Court that it had applied a presumption and that, in reply to a specific question, that institution had explained that the element of the file on which it had relied to systematically use the highest normal value of the other cooperating exporting producers was Sinopec Ningxia's lack of cooperation. The General Court concluded that, by applying such a presumption, the Commission had infringed Article 18 of the basic Regulation.
2. Brief summary of the arguments of the parties

• 19. By its first ground of appeal, the Commission, supported by Kuraray, submits that, in the judgment under appeal, the General Court erred in law in the interpretation and application of Article 18 of the basic Regulation. The Commission submits that, contrary to what the General Court held, the Commission did not apply, in recitals 329 and 333 of the regulation at issue, any 'presumption' based on Sinopec Ningxia's lack of cooperation. The Commission simply inferred from the fact that Sinopec Ningxia had not provided, on several occasions, the missing data that its normal values had to be at least at the level of the highest normal values for the same product types manufactured by the other cooperating exporting producers. In so doing, the Commission considers that it did not 'penalise' Sinopec Ningxia, but merely used data on the file relating to those other exporting producers. Furthermore, nowhere in its written pleadings at first instance did the Commission refer to such a presumption. The General Court therefore distorted the characterisation of its reasoning in recital 333 of the regulation at issue.
  • 20. As a preliminary point, Wegochem submits that the first ground of appeal of the Commission is inadmissible since it seeks to call into question factual findings made by the General Court in the judgment under appeal. According to Wegochem, the General Court found that the Commission had applied a presumption and that it had penalised Sinopec Ningxia. The Commission is therefore asking the Court to reassess the underlying evidence and facts.
  • 21. In essence, Sinopec, supported by Wegochem, submits, first, that the Commission did not make an inference but applied a presumption. Other than the reasoning in recital 333, the Commission did not present any evidence or reasoning to support the systematic selection of the highest normal value found per product type. The General Court rightly stated that the only element on which the Commission had relied was the lack of cooperation. It was therefore right in concluding that the Commission had applied a presumption. Second, even if the Commission had made an inference, this would not allow it to select a particular fact in order to punish non-cooperation. It is apparent from World Trade Organisation (WTO) case-law that if certain information has not been provided, an authority cannot simply assume that the missing information is necessarily incriminating and cannot read the missing information in the most negative light. Third, the Commission's concerns that the General Court's approach risks incentivising exporting producers to refuse selectively to cooperate is overblown. Article 18(6) of the basic Regulation does not require that the result must be less favourable. The Commission could have used other values such as the weighted average of the normal values of the other exporters which could also have been 'less favourable'. Instead, the Commission made sure that the selected replacement facts were the most adverse possible in regard to Sinopec.
3. Analysis
(a) Admissibility of the first ground of appeal and jurisdiction of the Court
22. As regards the plea of inadmissibility raised by Wegochem, it is apparent from settled case-law that an intervener has
no standing to raise a plea alleging that an action is inadmissible where such a plea is not set out in the form of an order sought by the defendant. (17)

• 23. In the present case, Sinopec did not raise any plea of admissibility relating to the first ground of appeal. It follows that Wegochem was not entitled to raise the plea of inadmissibility and that the Court is therefore not bound to consider such a plea.
  • 24. However, the question of the Court's jurisdiction to hear and determine a case is a matter of public policy, that may be considered by the Court at any stage in the proceedings, even of its own motion. (18)
  • 25. Accordingly, since, as is apparent from settled case-law, the Court has no jurisdiction to establish the facts on appeal, (19) save where the facts are distorted, (20) Wegochem's plea of admissibility raises an issue concerning the Court's jurisdiction that the Court should examine of its own motion.
  • 26. In the present case, however, the first ground of appeal does not seek to call into question considerations of fact. On the contrary, it raises a question of law concerning the interpretation of Article 18 of the basic Regulation and, in particular, the level of discretion available to the Commission when choosing to take into account the 'facts available' in cases of noncooperation by an interested party. Furthermore, the Commission contests the interpretation of recital 333 of the regulation at issue made in the judgment under appeal, submitting that the General Court distorted the meaning of that recital. The Court therefore has jurisdiction to address the first ground of the Commission's appeal.
(b) Substance

• (1) Article 18 of the basic Regulation
    • 27. To address the Commission's argument that, in the judgment under appeal, the General Court committed an error of law relating to Article 18 of the basic Regulation, it must be recalled at the outset that the basic Regulation does not confer on the Commission any power to compel the interested parties to participate in the investigation or to provide information. The Commission is therefore reliant on the voluntary cooperation of those parties in supplying the necessary information. (21)
    • 28. Accordingly, the EU legislature provided in Article 18(1) of the basic Regulation that, in cases in which an interested party does not provide necessary information, or significantly impedes the investigation, findings may be made on the basis of the 'facts available'. (22) Furthermore, under Article 18(6) of said regulation, if an interested party does not cooperate, the result of the investigation may be less favourable to that party than if it had cooperated.
    • 29. As is apparent from recital 27 of the basic Regulation, Article 18 thereof reflects the EU legislature's intention of streamlining the evidentiary task incumbent on the Commission when faced with material obstacles attributable to the lack of cooperation by the interested parties. (23) Accordingly, the Court has found that the objective of Article 18 of the basic Regulation is to enable the Commission to continue with the investigation even though the interested parties refuse to cooperate or do not cooperate adequately. (24)
    • 30. Against that background, interested parties are obliged to cooperate to the best of their ability and must provide all the information at their disposal which the institutions consider necessary for the purpose of making their findings. (25) Moreover, the risk that, where the interested parties in the investigation do not cooperate, the institutions may take into account 'facts available' which could be less favourable in accordance with Article 18(1) and (6) of the basic Regulation is inherent in the anti-dumping procedure and is designed to encourage the honest and diligent cooperation of those undertakings. (26)
    • 31. For the sake of the effectiveness and efficiency of the anti-dumping procedure, it must be ensured that interested parties cooperate genuinely and fully with the investigation, acting to the best of their ability and without impeding the investigation. The negative consequences to which an interested party may be exposed in the case of defective or partial cooperation – where an interested party may find itself in a less favourable situation than that which it would have been in if it had cooperated fully with the investigation – must function as an incentive to cooperate fully and unconditionally with the investigation. (27) Any other approach would risk undermining the efficiency of EU trade defence measures each time the EU institutions are faced with non-cooperation in an investigation. (28)
    • 32. It should also be emphasised that in the field of common commercial policy and, in particular, in the realm of measures to protect trade, the EU institutions enjoy a broad discretion by reason of the complexity of the economic, political and legal situations which they have to examine. (29) In that context, when the Commission bases its conclusions on the 'facts available' in situations where the facts submitted are deficient, that institution enjoys a broad discretion in choosing the most appropriate facts available on the file and is not required to explain why the facts available that were used were the most appropriate, since no such obligation is apparent either from Article 18 of the basic Regulation or from the case-law. (30)

• 33. Furthermore, according to settled case-law, the judicial review of such an appraisal must therefore be limited to verifying whether relevant procedural rules have been complied with, whether the facts relied on have been accurately stated, and whether there has been a manifest error in the appraisal of those facts or a misuse of powers. (31)
  • 34. Nevertheless, it is precisely in consideration of the Commission's discretion that a rigorous judicial review, albeit within the limits expressed above, is crucial. Specifically, the complex nature of the economic and legal assessments made by the Commission should not prevent the courts from examining whether the evidence relied on is factually accurate, reliable and consistent, whether that evidence contains all relevant information which should be taken into account in order to assess a complex situation and whether it is capable of substantiating the conclusions drawn therefrom. (32)
(2) Application to the present case

• 35. In the present case, it is undisputed that Sinopec Ningxia failed to provide reliable data relating to its cost of production and that, therefore, due to its lack of cooperation, the Commission could rely on 'facts available' in accordance with Article 18(1) of the basic Regulation to construct that company's normal value.
  • 36. The General Court, however, considered, in paragraph 218 of the judgment under appeal, that, in recitals 329 and 333 of the regulation at issue, following its finding of non-cooperation, the Commission had applied a presumption that Sinopec Ningxia's normal value, per product type, was not below the highest, per product type, of the normal values of the other exporting producers.
  • 37. A presumption can be generally defined as a legal mechanism whereby an uncertain fact (or set of facts) is (or are) inferred from a certain fact or set of facts. (33)
  • 38. Given that, under Article 18 of the basic Regulation, it is possible to make findings on the basis of the 'facts available' on the file and to treat a party which does not cooperate or does not cooperate fully less favourably than if it had cooperated, EU institutions are authorised to infer from the direct proof of the facts which they established from the information in their possession, indirect proof of the facts which remain unknown on account of the non-cooperation of the parties. In other words, Article 18 of the basic Regulation allows the EU institutions to act on the basis of presumptions provided that there is a logical and reasonable link between the facts established and those that remain unknown. Prohibiting those institutions from relying on such presumptions would have the effect of creating unreasonable obstacles to the adoption of EU trade defence measures each time the EU institutions are faced with non-cooperation in an investigation. (34)
  • 39. However, nowhere in the regulation at issue is it written that the Commission applied a presumption. Moreover, the Commission challenges the interpretation of the regulation at issue made by the General Court, arguing that said Court mischaracterises the meaning of recital 333 by concluding that it applied a presumption. The Commission also contests having acknowledged that it used a presumption.
  • 40. An attentive reading of recital 333 of the regulation at issue, as recalled in point 17 of the present Opinion, shows that, in that recital, the Commission did not establish or infer a fact or the likelihood of a fact from another fact. In that recital, the Commission merely rejected as unproven the argument submitted by Sinopec relating to the punitive character of its choice, among the 'facts available', of the highest normal value, per product type, of the normal values of the other cooperating exporting producers. The Commission simply stated that it was not established that that approach was punitive, since there was no element in the file showing that Sinopec Ningxia's normal value per product type would be below the highest normal value per product type of the other cooperating exporting producers that use similar raw materials.
  • 41. Consequently, first, since the Commission did not infer an (uncertain) fact from another (certain) fact, it cannot be considered in my view that that institution applied a presumption. The Commission did not determine or infer Sinopec Ningxia's normal value. It simply took note of the absence of any evidence substantiating the alleged punitive character of its systematic choice of the highest normal value of the other cooperating exporting producers.
  • 42. Second, since it is established that Sinopec Ningxia did not provide reliable data allowing the determination of its normal values, the statement contained in recital 333 of the regulation at issue relating to the absence of evidence allowing the Commission to assess whether those values would be below the values chosen is correct and not vitiated by any manifest error of assessment.
  • 43. In that regard, the mere existence of a possibility of relying on alternative data or facts available on the file is not sufficient to establish a manifest error of assessment by the Commission. As recalled above, the objective of Article 18 of the basic Regulation is to enable the Commission to conclude its investigation notwithstanding the temporary constraints imposed on it, including cases of non-cooperation, in which the Commission enjoys a broad discretion in examining and assessing the 'facts available'.
  • 44. In the exercise of its discretion, as is apparent from point 32 of the present Opinion, the Commission needs to choose

'facts available' that, while on file and sufficiently corroborating, ensure the efficiency and the effectiveness of EU trade defence measures also in cases of non-cooperation. The Commission cannot choose 'facts available' that risk rewarding non-cooperation in the investigation. Thus, in the absence of any reliable data on file concerning its costs, by reason of its own lack of cooperation, Sinopec cannot claim that alternative values such as the average normal value of the other cooperating exporting producers should be used, as this would possibly reward non-cooperation. As the Commission has rightly pointed out, the use of such a value may have the perversive effect of incentivising exporting producers to selectively refuse to cooperate in all the areas where they are aware that they incurred higher than average costs compared to other exporters. In any case, Sinopec did not provide any explanation as to why the Commission should have used that value rather than the highest normal value per product type of the other cooperating exporting producers.

• 45. Furthermore, it is not demonstrated that, by choosing such a normal value, the Commission selected the most unfavourable 'facts available' and thereby penalised Sinopec Ningxia. In fact, the data of the other cooperating exporting operators are not the only facts available that the Commission could have taken into account following Sinopec Ningxia's non-cooperation. As is apparent from Article 18(5) of the basic Regulation, 'facts available' may also include information provided by the European producers in their complaint, data available from independent sources such as published price lists, official statistics and customs records. In the light of those various sources which might have also been taken into account, it is not demonstrated that, by relying on the highest normal value per product type of the other cooperating exporting producers, the Commission ensured that the replacement data would be the most unfavourable for Sinopec Ningxia. The alleged punitive nature of that choice is therefore not substantiated.
  • 46. In any event, as mentioned above, the risk that, in cases of non-cooperation, the 'facts available' used may lead to a less favourable result under Article 18(6) of the basic Regulation is inherent in the anti-dumping procedure and Sinopec Ningxia ought to have been well aware of that risk.
  • 47. In conclusion, it follows from all the above considerations that, in paragraphs 211 to 221 of the judgment under appeal, the General Court mischaracterised the meaning of recital 333 of the regulation at issue and committed an error of law infringing Article 18 of the basic Regulation. Accordingly, the first ground of the Commission's appeal should, in my view, be upheld.
B. The second ground of appeal, relating to the infringement of Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation and of the principle of good administration

• 48. The second ground of the Commission's appeal raises significant questions concerning the interaction between the Commission's obligation to make a fair comparison under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation and the construction of the normal value under Article 2(6a) of the same regulation in cases of exports from countries whose domestic market has been shown to be subject to significant distortions. It also raises further important questions regarding the burden and standard of proof for the adjustments necessary to ensure that fair comparison.
  • 49. Article 2(6a)(a) of the basic Regulation provides as follows:

'In case it is determined, when applying this or any other relevant provision of [the basic Regulation], that it is not appropriate to use domestic prices and costs in the exporting country due to the existence in that country of significant distortions within the meaning of point (b), the normal value shall be constructed exclusively on the basis of costs of production and sale reflecting undistorted prices or benchmarks, subject to the following rules.
The sources the Commission may use include:

• corresponding costs of production and sale in an appropriate representative country with a similar level of economic development as the exporting country, provided the relevant data are readily available; …
  • if it considers appropriate, undistorted international prices, costs, or benchmarks; or
  • domestic costs, but only to the extent that they are positively established not to be distorted, on the basis of accurate and appropriate evidence …
…
The constructed normal value shall include an undistorted and reasonable amount for administrative, selling and general costs and for profits.'
50. Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation provides as follows:

'A fair comparison shall be made between the export price and the normal value. This comparison shall be made at the same level of trade and in respect of sales made at, as closely as possible, the same time and with due account taken of other differences which affect price comparability. Where the normal value and the export price as established are not on such a comparable basis, due allowance, in the form of adjustments, shall be made in each case, on its merits, for

differences in factors which are claimed, and demonstrated, to affect prices and price comparability. … When the specified conditions are met, the factors for which adjustment can be made are listed as [indicated in points (a) to (k)] …'

51. The second ground of the Commission's appeal concerns the General Court's findings in paragraphs 124 to 139 of the judgment under appeal, in which the General Court found that by deducting 'the costs at issue' (namely insurance costs, transport, handling and loading expenses, credit costs and bank charges) from the export price, the Commission had infringed its obligation to make a fair comparison at the same level of trade under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation, since such costs had likely not been deducted from the constructed normal value.
1. Background to the disputed issue

• 52. In the regulation at issue, (35) the Commission constructed the normal value in accordance with the method laid down in Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation for exporting countries with significant distortions. The constructed normal value was based on the undistorted values in the representative country (Türkiye), plus 17.6% for SG&A costs and 4% for profits. The SG&A costs were calculated on the basis of data relating to a Turkish producer, Ilkalem Ticaret Ve Sanayi A.S. ('Ilkalem'). (36) In recital 341 of the regulation at issue, the Commission concluded that the normal value had been constructed per product type on an 'ex-works' basis.
  • 53. To bring the export price to the same level of trade as the normal value, namely the 'ex-works' level, the Commission deducted 'the costs at issue' from the export price. (37)
  • 54. In their comments on final disclosure, Sinopec contested the fact that the Commission had removed 'the costs at issue' from the export price, whilst these costs had, allegedly, not been removed from the SG&A costs of the producer in the representative country. (38)
  • 55. The Commission addressed that issue in recital 314 of the regulation at issue, which is worded as follows:

'The Commission disagreed with this claim. The Commission noted that there is nothing indicating that such expenses were included in SG&A costs reported for the producer in the representative country. Furthermore, the sampled exporting producers provided no evidence to the contrary. This claim was therefore rejected.'

• 56. Sinopec challenged that conclusion before the General Court, arguing that the Commission had infringed Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation.
  • 57. The General Court upheld that plea. First, in paragraphs 124 to 127 of the judgment under appeal, it considered that adjustments to establish the 'ex-works' level of the export price are necessary to ensure the 'fair comparison' required by Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation only if the normal value is also calculated at the 'ex-works' level. Therefore, according to the General Court, on the basis of the case-law, it was for the Commission, which had chosen to make the comparison at issue at the 'ex-works' level, to demonstrate that those adjustments were necessary in order for the comparison to be fair.
  • 58. Second, in paragraphs 128 to 139 of the judgment under appeal, the General Court considered that, in any event, on the assumption that the burden of proof rested with Sinopec and not on the Commission, Sinopec had duly substantiated its request for adjustments. The General Court found that the Commission had based the calculation of the SG&A costs on data relating to Ilkalem taken from the 'Orbis database' that were not granular enough to rule out that they included 'the costs at issue'. Consequently, that Court held that the Commission, which did not have a more precise breakdown of Ilkalem's SG&A costs, could not reasonably require Sinopec to further substantiate its request for adjustment of the normal value by producing data for an unrelated party that were more precise than the data the Commission itself held. Therefore, according to the General Court, in recital 314 of the regulation at issue, the Commission required Sinopec to adduce unreasonable proof. Moreover, the General Court concluded that, unlike the situation in the judgment in Changmao, (39) the Commission did not provide Sinopec with data that would have enabled it further to substantiate its request for adjustment.
2. Brief summary of the arguments of the parties

• 59. The second ground of the Commission's appeal is divided into two limbs.
  • 60. By the first limb, the Commission, supported by Kuraray, challenges paragraphs 126 and 127 of the judgment under appeal. The Commission submits that the General Court misinterpreted Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation and reversed the well-established rules relating to the burden of proof for adjustments. According to the Commission, the General Court conflated its obligations under Article 2(6a) and Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation.
  • 61. By the second limb, the Commission challenges paragraphs 128 to 139 of the judgment under appeal. First, the Commission submits that the General Court distorted the facts when it stated that Sinopec, in the comments on final disclosure, had claimed that the SG&A costs used in the construction of the normal value 'in all likelihood' included 'the costs at issue'. In fact, no likelihood analysis was made in the comments on final disclosure. That argument was raised only by Wegochem in its intervention before the General Court. Second, the General Court misapplied the standard of proof

under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation. The General Court merely established that it cannot be 'ruled out' that Ilkalem's data used to establish the constructed SG&A costs included 'the costs at issue'. Thus, the General Court did not properly establish that the constructed normal value actually or even likely included 'the costs at issue'. Third, the General Court misapplied the principle of good administration by finding that the Commission had imposed an unreasonable burden of proof on Sinopec, despite having disclosed all the data it had in relation to the adjustment claimed.

• 62. As regards the first limb, preliminarily, Wegochem submits that that limb is ineffective because paragraphs 126 and 127 of the judgment under appeal do not support the operative part of that judgment. Then, Sinopec, supported by Wegochem, submits, first, that that limb is based on the erroneous premiss that for expenses that are part of the 'nettingback process' there is no need to demonstrate that they are factors affecting price comparability, whereas such an obligation exists for expenses that are not part of the 'netting-back process'. However, both EU and WTO law and case-law contradict that approach. The Commission bears the burden of proving the existence of a difference affecting price comparability for any adjustment it makes. Second – and in any event – Sinopec submits that the Commission's reasoning for 'netting back' the export price to the 'ex-works' level was flawed since there was no evidence that the normal value calculated pursuant to Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation was also at the 'ex-works' level. The statement in the regulation at issue that the normal value was constructed at the 'ex-works' level was unsubstantiated.
  • 63. As regards the second limb, Sinopec, first, contests the alleged distortion of the facts. In the comments on final disclosure Sinopec did refer – independently of Wegochem – to the likelihood that an 'ex-works' export price was being compared to a normal value at a different level of trade. Second, the request for an adjustment was duly substantiated and the General Court applied the correct standard of proof. It does not need to be positively established that the amount of the SG&A expenses included 'the costs at issue'. According to consistent EU case-law, it is sufficient that something cannot be ruled out. Third, as regards the misapplication of the principle of good administration, the situation in the judgment in Changmao was different from the one in the present case.
3. Analysis

64. Given that the second ground of appeal raises the issue of the interaction between Article 2(6a) and Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation, I consider it appropriate first to clarify the context of those provisions in light of the existing case-law (sections (a) and (b)) and then to analyse the two limbs of the second ground of appeal (sections (c) and (d)).
(a) The construction of the normal value under Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation

• 65. Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation recalled in point 49 of the present Opinion establishes a special regime laying down rules for determining the normal value in the case of exports from countries whose domestic market has been shown to have significant distortions, as defined in that provision. That special regime was introduced by Regulation (EU) 2017/2321, (40) which amended Article 2 of the basic Regulation by inserting a new paragraph 6a and by modifying paragraph 7, which, prior to that amendment, established a special regime for the calculation of the normal value for imports from 'non-market economy countries'.
  • 66. While, pursuant to the previous version of Article 2(7) of the basic Regulation, the normal value for non-market economy countries was determined based on actual prices and costs of a cooperating producer in a market-economy third country, under the new Article 2(6a) methodology, the normal value of exporting producers is to be constructed based on hypothetical undistorted costs of production and reasonable amounts for SG&A costs and for profit.
  • 67. As the Commission explained, when it applies the Article 2(6a) methodology, after requesting information from exporting producers indicating the factors of production and the quantities that are used to manufacture each type of the product concerned, the Commission then determines undistorted values for the factors of production used based on 'readily available' information, as provided for in Article 2(6a)(a), first indent, of the basic Regulation, and replaces the distorted prices and costs with those values in order to establish the undistorted costs of production.
  • 68. As regards the SG&A costs at issue in the present ground of appeal the last subparagraph of Article 2(6a)(a) of the basic Regulation mandates that, to construct the normal value based on undistorted costs, an 'undistorted and reasonable' amount for SG&A costs and for profits must be added.
  • 69. The objective of Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation is to prevent distorted data relating to prices and costs in the exporting country from being used for the purposes of anti-dumping investigations. (41)
  • 70. Furthermore, as was the case for the previous version of Article 2(7) concerning 'non-market economy countries', Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation too is the expression of the EU legislature's intention to adopt an approach specific to the EU legal order by establishing a special regime of detailed rules for the calculation of the normal value for imports where significant distortions exist in the exporting country. Accordingly, as the General Court rightly pointed out, (42) in accordance with the principles developed by the case-law relating to the previous version of Article 2(7), Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation cannot be considered to be a measure intended to ensure the implementation in the EU legal order of a particular obligation assumed in the context of the WTO agreements. In fact, WTO law did not lay down rules for the
calculation of the normal value for imports in case of the existence of significant distortions in the exporting country. (43)

• 71. In the same vein, the case-law relating to the previous version of Article 2(7), according to which the EU institutions enjoy broad discretion when determining the normal value in respect of non-market economy countries, (44) shall also be considered applicable to the determination of the normal value under Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation.
  • 72. In that regard, the determination of reasonable margins for SG&A costs is no exception to the application of that caselaw. Moreover, the last subparagraph of Article 2(6a)(a) of the basic Regulation does not prescribe any particular methodology for establishing those margins. Thus, within the two parameters given (namely 'undistorted and reasonable'), the Commission enjoys considerable discretion. This is also true as regards the database used to collect the relevant data for the construction of the normal value and of the SG&A costs. (45)
  • 73. Accordingly, it is for the party seeking to dispute the reliability of the data used by the Commission for the purposes of calculating the SG&A costs to substantiate their assertions with evidence capable of casting specific doubt on the credibility of the method or data used by that institution. (46)
(b) The obligation to make a fair comparison under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation

• 74. Pursuant to Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation recalled in point 50 of the present Opinion a fair comparison must be made between the export price and the normal value, at the same level of trade. Where a fair comparison cannot be made between the normal value and the export price, due allowance is to be made, in the form of adjustments, for differences in factors which are claimed and demonstrated to affect prices and price comparability.
  • 75. The text of the first sentence of Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation is clearly drawn from the first sentence of Article 2.4 of the Anti-Dumping Agreement, in that it uses essentially the same terms. (47) It is thus possible to infer that, at least in terms of the obligation to make a 'fair comparison' between the export price and the normal value at the same level of trade, the text of that provision demonstrates the clear intention of the EU legislature to implement in EU law the specific obligation laid down in Article 2.4 of the Anti-Dumping Agreement. (48)
  • (1) The fair comparison at the same level of trade
    • 76. Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation requires that the fair comparison be made at the same level of trade, without specifying at which level such a comparison should be made. It is therefore for the Commission to choose the appropriate level of trade within its margin of discretion. (49) Although a comparison at the same level of trade does not exhaust the obligation to make a fair comparison, (50) it is one of the basic parameters that 'further the goal of achieving a fair comparison'. (51) Consequently, a comparison between normal value and export price at different levels of trade can never be considered fair.
    • 77. In order to compare the normal value and the export price at the same level of trade it may be necessary to adjust those values so as to remove elements or costs that are not incurred at the level of trade chosen for the comparison. (52) In fact, an imbalance would occur in the comparison of the normal value and the export price if no adjustments were made in accordance with Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation, consisting in a deduction from the export price (or, alternatively, from the normal value) of the costs that are not included in the determination of the normal value (or, alternatively, of the export price) at the level of trade chosen for the comparison. (53)
    • 78. That process is known as the 'netting back' of the normal value and the export price to the same level of trade. It consists in eliminating from both values elements that are foreign to the level of trade chosen for the comparison. In fact, the aim of the adjustments under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation is to re-establish the symmetry between normal value and export price, (54) in particular, at the same level of trade.
    • 79. Accordingly, pursuant to the consistent case-law of the EU Courts, it is apparent from the wording and broad scheme of Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation that an adjustment to the export price or to the normal value may be made only to take account of differences in relation to factors which affect both prices, and which thus affect their comparability, in order to ensure that the comparison is made at the same level of trade. (55)
  • (2) The fair comparison when the normal value is constructed under Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation
    • 80. The obligation to make a fair comparison at the same level of trade under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation and the case-law relating to it undoubtedly also apply when the normal value is constructed under Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation. However, in that case the perspective is usually slightly different from cases in which the normal value is determined under the ordinary rules. In fact, when the normal value is constructed under Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation the Commission relies on hypothetical undistorted costs of production and reasonable amounts for SG&A costs and for profits. Thus, instead of removing, through the 'netting-back' exercise, costs that do not belong to the level of trade chosen for the comparison, the Commission should rather first construct the normal value at the level of trade chosen by using upfront 'readily available' data that do not include costs of that type.

• 81. In that regard, as observed, in essence, in the judgment of the General Court in CCCME, although the practice of making adjustments may prove to be necessary, under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation, to take account of differences between the export price and the normal value which affect their comparability, certain deductions cannot be made with respect to a value which has been constructed and which is not, therefore, genuine. That value is not generally affected by factors which might damage its comparability, because it has been artificially established by adding together various items, but not including items that must be deducted. (56)
  • 82. In sum, whenever the Commission constructs the normal value under Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation on the basis of 'readily available' data at the level of trade chosen for the comparison (including SG&A costs that have been determined, within its broad margin of discretion, as 'undistorted and reasonable' at that level of trade), there is no reason to make adjustments to net back further the normal value, unless it is demonstrated that that value (or the related SG&A costs) contains elements that are foreign to that level of trade.
  • 83. In that context, with regard to the fair comparison between the normal value constructed under Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation and the export price, it must be noted that the Court has stated, with specific reference to SG&A costs, that since different rules apply for the determination of normal value and export price, the sales, general and administrative expenses need not necessarily be treated in the same way in both cases. (57)
(3) The burden and standard of proof relating to adjustments

• 84. It is apparent from the consistent case-law of the Court that, if a party claims adjustments under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation in order to make the normal value and the export price comparable for the purpose of determining the dumping margin, that party must prove that its claim is justified. Accordingly, the burden of proving that the specific adjustments must be made lies with those who wish to rely on them, irrespective of who they are. It follows that it is for the party wishing to rely on such an adjustment to demonstrate that the factor in respect of which that adjustment is requested is capable of affecting prices and price comparability. (58)
  • 85. Thus, where a producer claims that an adjustment of the normal value, in principle downward, or an adjustment of the export price, logically upward, applies, it is for that operator to indicate and to establish that the conditions for granting such an adjustment are satisfied. Conversely, where the Commission considers that it is appropriate to apply a downward adjustment of the export price it is the responsibility of that institution to adduce at the very least consistent evidence showing that the condition required to carry out the adjustment is fulfilled. (59)
  • 86. The Court has recently confirmed that the rule, according to which it is for the party requesting an adjustment in respect of one of the factors referred to in Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation to demonstrate that that factor is such as to affect prices and price comparability, applies irrespective of the method used to determine the normal value. (60)
  • 87. Consequently, the fact that normal value is constructed on the basis of Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation and therefore on the basis of data from exporting producers from the appropriate representative country cannot lower the burden of proof arising from the case-law cited in point 84 above. (61)
(c) The first limb of the second ground of appeal

• 88. Preliminarily, contrary to Wegochem's argument, I do not think that the first limb of the second ground of appeal is ineffective. The General Court's conclusion – in paragraph 139 of the judgment under appeal – that Sinopec's plea had to be upheld is based on two alternative sets of reasoning. (62) The first limb is directed against the first set of that reasoning (contained in paragraphs 124 to 127 of the judgment under appeal and recalled in point 57 of the present Opinion). If that part of the judgment were maintained, then the General Court's conclusion that Sinopec's plea should be upheld would stand, making it unnecessary to analyse the second limb. The first limb is therefore effective.
  • 89. The first limb of the second ground of appeal concerns, in essence, the issue of the burden of proof regarding the adjustments consisting in the deduction of 'the costs at issue' from the export price. The Commission challenges the General Court's conclusion, in paragraph 127 of the judgment under appeal, that it was for the Commission 'to demonstrate that those adjustments were necessary in order for the comparison of the export price and the normal value to be fair'.
  • 90. To address that issue, it is fundamental to keep the factual background described in points 52 to 55 of the present Opinion in mind. In the present case, the Commission constructed the normal value in accordance with Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation. In recital 341 of the regulation at issue, the Commission concluded that the normal value had been constructed on an 'ex-works' basis.
  • 91. To ensure a fair comparison at the same level of trade in accordance with Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation, the Commission had to establish the export price at the same level of trade, namely the 'ex-works' level. To bring the export price to that level of trade the Commission deducted 'the costs at issue' from the export price, thus carrying out the 'nettingback process' mentioned in points 77 and 78 of the present Opinion.

• 92. It is undisputed that 'the costs at issue' are not attributable to the 'ex-works' level of trade chosen by the Commission and that, therefore, the deduction of those costs was necessary to bring the export price to the 'ex-works' level.
  • 93. In fact, both before the Commission and before the General Court, Sinopec did not contest the necessity of the deduction of those costs from the export price to bring that value to the 'ex-works' level. Sinopec rather contested the fairness of the comparison between the export price and the constructed normal value in so far as it argued that 'the costs at issue' were possibly included in the constructed normal value. Sinopec explicitly put into doubt that the normal value had been constructed at the 'ex-works' level.
  • 94. Consequently, it is Sinopec that asked for an adjustment of the constructed normal value to ensure the fair comparison. Alternatively, for the same reason (namely because, according to Sinopec, the normal value had not been constructed at the 'ex-works' level), Sinopec asked the Commission not to carry out the 'netting back' of 'the costs at issue' from the export price. That reading of the facts is explicitly confirmed both by the wording of paragraph 128 of the judgment under appeal and by the submissions of Sinopec and Wegochem themselves.
  • 95. Against that background, two considerations apply.
  • 96. First, I believe that, in the present case, the Commission met the burden of proof it bears (as required by the case-law mentioned in points 84 and 85 of the present Opinion) relating to the necessity to make the downward adjustment to the export price in order to bring it to the 'ex-works' level of trade chosen for the fair comparison.
  • 97. Once it became clear from the file that the export price contained elements ('the costs at issue') that did not belong to that level of trade, the necessity to deduct such costs was self-evident (in re ipsa). (63) In fact, as recalled in point 76 of the present Opinion, a comparison at different levels of trade can never be fair. Contrary to what Sinopec and Wegochem argue, there was no need to further demonstrate that those expenses were factors affecting price comparability. Since they did not belong to the level of trade chosen for the comparison, those expenses by definition affected price comparability. (64)
  • 98. Of course, given its obligation to guarantee a fair comparison under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation, the Commission needed to ensure that the normal value was also constructed at the same level of trade, namely at the 'exworks' level. However, this is an issue concerning the determination of the normal value and not the netting back of the export price. The Commission had concluded in recital 341 of the regulation at issue that the normal value had been constructed at the 'ex-works' level. As long as it is not established that that conclusion was wrong and that the normal value was not constructed at that level – which, as will be seen below, was not demonstrated – this issue does not concern the netting back of the export price at the level of trade chosen for the comparison.
  • 99. Second, as is apparent from point 93 of the present Opinion, it is Sinopec that alleged, contrary to the Commission's finding, that the normal value had not been constructed at the 'ex-works' level and that therefore asked for an adjustment of that normal value to ensure a fair comparison. Consequently, according to the case-law mentioned in points 84 and 85 of the present Opinion, it was Sinopec that bore the burden of proof to demonstrate that it was necessary to make an adjustment to the normal value to achieve the 'ex-works' level or, alternatively, that the deduction of 'the costs at issue' for the netting back of the export price at that level of trade chosen for the fair comparison was not necessary.
  • 100. The General Court therefore committed an error of law when it concluded, in essence, in paragraphs 126 and 127 of the judgment under appeal, that the Commission had erred in not demonstrating that the deductions of 'the costs at issue' from the export price 'were necessary in order for the comparison … to be fair'. In fact, the Commission had demonstrated the necessity for the downward adjustments of the export price to bring it to the level of trade chosen for the fair comparison. It was rather Sinopec that had argued that the normal value was not constructed at that level of trade and that therefore it was necessary to adjust it to ensure the fair comparison. It was thus for Sinopec to substantiate its allegations.
  • 101. That conclusion is not called into question by Sinopec's argument according to which there was no evidence that the normal value constructed pursuant to Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation was also at the 'ex-works' level.
  • 102. It is true, as Sinopec argues, that a normal value constructed using the methodology of Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation is not necessarily and by definition established at the 'ex-works' level. A constructed normal value is, however, at the 'ex-works' level if the Commission, when constructing it, includes only elements present at that level of trade.
  • 103. Ultimately, when the Commission determines the normal value under Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation, whether that normal value is or not constructed at the 'ex-works' level depends on the data used for its construction. As is apparent from points 80 to 82 of the present Opinion, the Commission should not use, for the calculation of the SG&C costs that will be included in the constructed normal value at the 'ex-works' level, data which contain expenses that are not incurred at that level of trade. If the Commission uses such data, it will have to adjust the constructed normal value by deducting those expenses.
  • 104. However, this is exactly what Sinopec was arguing and should have demonstrated in order for the requested

adjustment to the constructed normal value to be carried out. This is an issue which concerns the merits of the second limb, which relates to the standard of proof. It has no impact on the question of who carries the burden of proof, namely, in the present case, Sinopec, which was contesting that the normal value had been constructed at the ex-works level of trade and asked for an adjustment.
105. In the light of all the foregoing considerations, I consider that the first limb of the Commission's second ground of appeal should be upheld.
(d) The second limb of the second ground of appeal

106. The second limb of the second ground of appeal is directed against paragraphs 128 to 139 of the judgment under appeal, in which the General Court analysed the alternative scenario in which the burden of proof for the adjustments at issue rested with Sinopec. (65) This limb raises three questions relating, first, to the alleged distortion of facts by the General Court (section (d)(1)); second, to the standard of proof for the adjustment of the normal value requested by Sinopec (section (d)(2)); and, third, to the alleged breach of the principle of good administration committed by the Commission in requiring proof that was unreasonable (section (d)(3)).
(1) The alleged distortion of facts

• 107. First, it is necessary to address the Commission's argument alleging that the General Court distorted the facts by considering, in paragraph 128 of the judgment under appeal, that, in its comments on final disclosure, Sinopec had claimed that the normal value had been constructed by including, 'in all likelihood', 'the costs at issue'.
  • 108. The case-law sets a high threshold for establishing a distortion of facts. The General Court must have made findings of fact which the documents in the file show to be substantially incorrect. The distortion must be obvious from those documents and the General Court must have manifestly exceeded the limits of a reasonable assessment of the evidence. (66)
  • 109. In the present case, a reading of Sinopec's comments on final disclosure shows that, in that document, Sinopec contested that while 'the costs at issue' had been deducted from the export price to bring it to the 'ex-works' level, the same exercise had not been undertaken for the constructed normal value. Sinopec submitted that, therefore, the Commission was comparing an ex-works export price with a constructed normal value for which it was unclear at which level of trade that constructed normal value was established. Thus, the normal value was established 'at a, presumably, delivered basis'.
  • 110. That textual analysis of the comments on final disclosure shows that, as the Commission submits, there was no specific 'likelihood analysis' in Sinopec's submission. It is apparent from the Court's file that the likelihood scenario was indeed first developed by Wegochem before the General Court.
  • 111. Apart from this, the description of Sinopec's claim made by the General Court in paragraph 128 of the judgment under appeal is not substantially incorrect. The essence of that claim (namely the deduction of 'the costs at issue' from the export price and not from the constructed normal value) is clearly set out. Furthermore, the use of the term 'presumably' – albeit expressing a lesser level of certainty than the term 'in all likelihood' – implies a certain likelihood analysis.
  • 112. Thus, I do not think that the high threshold necessary to establish a distortion of facts is met in the present case. However, according to settled case-law, the legality of an act of the Commission is to be assessed in the light of the information available to the Commission when the act was adopted. (67) It will therefore be necessary to assess on the merits whether Sinopec duly substantiated its request for the adjustment of the normal value at issue by only referring to its submission as recalled in point 109 of the present Opinion and not on the basis of subsequent arguments added to that submission.
  • (2) The required standard of proof under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation
    • 113. Second, it is necessary to examine the Commission's argument that the General Court misapplied the standard of proof for adjustments under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation.
    • 114. As regards the standard of proof required for adjustments under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation, the case-law cited in point 85 of the present Opinion clarifies that where a producer claims that an adjustment of the normal value, in principle downward, applies, it is for that operator to indicate and to establish that the conditions for granting such an adjustment are satisfied.
    • 115. As regards, specifically, the SG&A costs constructed under the last subparagraph of Article 2(6a)(a) of the basic Regulation, according to the case-law of the General Court mentioned in point 73 of the present Opinion, it is for the party seeking to dispute the reliability of the data used by the Commission to substantiate their assertions with evidence capable of casting specific doubt on the credibility of the method or data used by the Commission.
    • 116. In the judgment under appeal, the General Court concluded in paragraph 128 that Sinopec had duly substantiated its

request to make the adjustment to the normal value, specifically to the SG&A costs, to ensure a fair comparison. The General Court also found, in paragraph 132 of the judgment under appeal, that it could not be ruled out that the data relating to the Turkish company Ilkalem taken from the Orbis database used by the Commission for establishing the SG&A costs included 'the costs at issue'. It factually established that those data were not granular or precise enough to determine with certitude whether 'the costs at issue' were included or not in those data. (68)

• 117. A first conclusion that can be drawn directly from the judgment under appeal is that it has not been definitely established, either during the Commission's investigation or even at the level of the General Court, that 'the costs at issue' were actually included in the data used by the Commission to construct the SG&A costs under the last subparagraph of Article 2(6a)(a) of the basic Regulation. If Sinopec had established that such costs were included in those data, it is apparent from points 80 and 82 of the present Opinion that the Commission should have made an adjustment to the constructed normal value in order to remove those elements that would be foreign to the level of trade chosen for the fair comparison. However, this was clearly not the case here.
  • 118. Against that background, I do not think that it can be considered that, in its request for adjustments recalled in point 109 of the present Opinion, Sinopec established that the conditions for granting such an adjustment were satisfied as required by the case-law mentioned in point 114 of the present Opinion. Of course, this was a particularly difficult task in that the relevant data concerned a third party, the Turkish producer Ilkalem, and the Commission itself did not have in its possession data allowing it to establish whether 'the costs at issue' were included or not in those data. (69)
  • 119. In that context, it may still be questioned, first, whether, on the basis of the doubts expressed in Sinopec's comments on final disclosure, the Commission should have nevertheless discarded the data from the Orbis database, because they were not precise enough to determine whether 'the costs at issue' would be included or not in the constructed SG&A costs.
  • 120. However, in that regard, it should be noted that, in recital 215 of the regulation at issue, the Commission stated that the available data for Ilkalem was 'generally on the same level of detail as any publicly available financial data normally used by the Commission in [anti-dumping] investigations. Therefore, the level of detail currently available for this company contains all the necessary information and does not make the company unsuitable for this investigation.' Sinopec did not contest these statements. It did not contest the suitability of those data to construct the SG&A costs. Thus, there was no reason for the Commission to discard those data.
  • 121. Second, it may also be questioned whether, on the basis of the doubts expressed in Sinopec's comments on final disclosure, the Commission should nevertheless have searched for more precise data in order to ensure a fair comparison under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation.
  • 122. In that regard, it should be recalled that, under Article 2(6a)(a) of the basic Regulation, the Commission should construct the normal value on the basis of 'readily available data'.
  • 123. The 'readily available' requirement ensures that, in the context of the construction of the normal value under Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation, the Commission uses data that can be accessed and verified swiftly. (70) It also ensures that, in the construction of the normal value, the Commission uses data that are publicly accessible or otherwise verifiable by interested parties (while respecting the confidentiality of the data), who can therefore comment on those data during the investigation. This is crucial for the procedural fairness of the construction of the normal value and due process. (71)
  • 124. It is certainly for the Commission to ensure the fairness of the comparison under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation, including when the normal value is constructed under Article 2(6a) of that regulation based on 'readily available' data. However, as recalled in point 27 of the present Opinion, the investigatory powers of the Commission in anti-dumping procedures are limited in that the basic Regulation does not confer on the Commission any power of investigation allowing it to compel companies to participate in the investigation or to provide information.
  • 125. In that context, in recital 238 of the regulation at issue, the Commission stated that 'further breakdown of the SG&A costs of [Ilkalem] was not readily available'. In the same recital the Commission rightly observed that the basic Regulation provides that the Commission must use information which is 'readily available' and does not foresee any requests to producers in the representative country. It also stated that even if it was possible to request and verify such information from those producers, it would most likely concern confidential data. Sinopec has not contested these statements. Moreover, in their submissions, both Sinopec and Wegochem do not specify how or where the Commission could have found more precise data.
  • 126. More generally, it is not excluded that, in certain cases, the 'readily available data' that the Commission uses to construct the normal value are not detailed enough to rebut claims for adjustment that, like in the present case, are themselves not sufficiently substantiated.
  • 127. However, this does not imply that, in such cases, the Commission cannot use that data to construct the normal value. This is even more true when the suitability of the data used is not itself called into question. (72) The Court's case-law confirms that it is not unreasonable or inappropriate to proceed with the determination of the normal value based on such
data. (73)

• 128. Moreover, as recalled in point 72 of the present Opinion, the Commission enjoys broad discretion in establishing undistorted and reasonable SG&A costs to be used in the construction of the normal value under Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation. Consequently, the standard of judicial review in that context is that of a manifest error of assessment. (74) It follows that the elements relied on by an applicant to invalidate that assessment need to be sufficient to render the analysis implausible. This has not happened in the present case.
  • 129. In conclusion, all the foregoing considerations entail two consequences.
  • 130. On the one hand, the General Court committed an error of law as regards the standard of proof required for adjustments under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation in concluding that, in its comments on final disclosure, Sinopec duly substantiated its request for an adjustment of the constructed normal value.
  • 131. On the other hand, although the General Court did not state expressly in the judgment under appeal that, as a consequence of Sinopec's request for adjustment, to ensure a fair comparison, the Commission should have made the adjustment to the normal value requested, such a conclusion can be deduced from the fact that the General Court upheld Sinopec's plea relating to the infringement of Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation.
  • 132. However, while, as noted in point 92 of the present Opinion, for the export price it was undisputed that 'the costs at issue' needed to be deducted since they did not belong to the level of trade chosen for the comparison, for the constructed normal value there was no precise indication and it had not been not demonstrated, as the General Court itself established, that those costs were included in the data used for constructing the SG&A costs. (75) This is exactly what the Commission stated in the first sentence of recital 314 of the regulation at issue, (76) which is therefore not erroneous in that regard.
  • 133. Thus, by upholding Sinopec's plea and by considering, in essence, that the conditions for granting the adjustments at issue of the constructed normal value were satisfied in the present case, the General Court committed another error of law relating to the standard of proof required for adjustments under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation.
  • (3) The alleged breach of the principle of good administration
    • 134. Finally, it is necessary to assess the Commission's argument relating to the allegedly erroneous finding by the General Court of a breach of the principle of good administration.
    • 135. That last argument of the second limb of the second ground of appeal concerns two reproaches made by the General Court. First, in paragraphs 134 and 135 of the judgment under appeal, the General Court ruled that by requiring Sinopec to further substantiate its request for adjustment by producing data relating to an unrelated party that were more precise than the data that it itself held, the Commission required unreasonable proof. Second, in paragraph 138 of the judgment under appeal, the General Court also reproached the Commission for not having provided Sinopec with data that would have enabled it further to substantiate its request for adjustment.
    • 136. Preliminarily, as the General Court rightly observed, Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation does not specifically reproduce the provision contained in the final sentence of Article 2.4 of the Anti-Dumping Agreement, according to which the 'authorities shall indicate to the parties in question what information is necessary to ensure a fair comparison and shall not impose an unreasonable burden of proof on those parties'. (77) That provision does not appear to have been specifically transposed in any other article of the basic Regulation. Consequently, it cannot be inferred from Article 2(10), or from any other provision of that regulation, that there was a clear intention on the part of the EU legislature to implement a particular obligation arising from the provision laid down in the final sentence of Article 2.4 of the Anti-Dumping Agreement. (78)
    • 137. While Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation, as such, does not lay down any positive obligation for the EU institutions to provide specific information to the interested parties concerning possible adjustments to ensure a fair comparison, this does not mean, however, that the basic Regulation does not take into consideration the requirements set out in the final sentence of Article 2.4 of the Anti-Dumping Agreement. Those requirements form part of the procedural system created by the EU legislature in connection with the anti-dumping proceedings implemented by the institutions on the basis of that regulation, interpreted in the light of the principle of good administration enshrined in Article 41 of the Charter of Fundamental rights. (79)
    • 138. As regards the first reproach by the General Court, relating to the imposition of an unreasonable burden of proof, it refers to recital 314 of the regulation at issue (recalled in point 55 of the present Opinion).
    • 139. In that recital the Commission found, first, that there was nothing indicating that 'the costs at issue' were included in SG&A costs reported for the Turkish producer and, second, that, 'furthermore', Sinopec had 'provided no evidence to the contrary'. Thus, in that recital, in essence, the Commission rejected as unsubstantiated Sinopec's request for adjustment of the normal value made in its comments on final disclosure (recalled in point 109 of the present Opinion).

140. As recalled in point 112 of the present Opinion, the legality of that rejection is to be assessed in the light of the information submitted by Sinopec and not on the basis of subsequent arguments added afterwards. In that regard, the arguments brought before the General Court, especially by Wegochem, show that Sinopec's request could have been undoubtedly more substantiated than it has been, so as to cast more doubt on the data contained in the Orbis database used by the Commission. Thus, the argument relating to the alleged impossible burden of proof is not capable of remedying the fact that the request for the adjustment of the constructed normal value was not sufficiently substantiated.

141. In any event, even if it had been unreasonably difficult for Sinopec to establish, as required by the case-law mentioned in point 114 of the present Opinion, that 'the costs at issue' were included in Ilkalem's data contained in the Orbis database, it is nevertheless apparent from points 125 and 126 of the present Opinion that, in the absence of definitive certainty as to certain alleged circumstances concerning the 'readily available' information used for the construction of the normal value under Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation, the Commission was entitled to proceed with the use of those data to construct the normal value even if they were not detailed enough to definitively rebut the unsubstantiated claim for adjustment.

142. In that regard, it must also be noted, from a broader policy perspective, that, in the context of the methodology under Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation, admitting claims for adjustments of the constructed normal value that are not substantiated to the legal standard as required by the case-law mentioned in points 114 and 115 of the present Opinion would entail the risk of undermining the whole methodology based on readily available data.
143. The second reproach by the General Court relates to the fact that Commission did not provide Sinopec with data that would have enabled it to further substantiate its request.

144. In that regard, while, as observed in point 137 of the present Opinion, the procedural system created by the basic Regulation for anti-dumping proceedings, read in the light of the principle of good administration, provides that the parties have some procedural rights in connection with the information necessary for a fair comparison under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation to be made, it is not written anywhere that the Commission should provide the interested parties with information that it does not have in its file. This means one of two things: either the parties argue that the Commission did not collect sufficient data and therefore claim a breach of the Commission's duty of care during the investigation; however, it is apparent from points 119 to 128 of the present Opinion that this is not the case in the present case; or they cannot claim a breach of the principle of good administration because they did not receive information which is not on the file.

145. Once it is established that the Commission provided the parties with all the relevant and shareable information that was on the file, there cannot be any breach of the principle of good administration merely because the Commission did not provide an interested party with data that would have enabled it to further substantiate its request. That conclusion is confirmed by the judgment in Changmao , in which the Court concluded that, in such a situation, an applicant cannot validly complain that the Commission failed to act in accordance with the principle of sound administration and violated its rights of defence by imposing an unreasonable burden of proof on it. (80)

146. It follows from all the above considerations that the third argument of the second ground of appeal should, in my opinion, also be upheld and, consequently, that the second ground of the Commission's appeal should be upheld in its entirety.
C. The third ground of appeal, relating to the interpretation of Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation

147. The third ground of the Commission's appeal concerns the General Court's findings in paragraphs 65 to 113 of the judgment under appeal, in which that Court held that the Commission had infringed Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation by applying a downward adjustment to the export price pursuant to that provision.

148. According to Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation, 'an adjustment shall be made for differences in commissions paid in respect of the sales under consideration.
