The term "commissions" shall be understood to include the mark-up received by a trader of the product or the like product if the functions of such a trader are similar to those of an agent working on a commission basis.'
1. Background to the disputed issue

149. As is apparent from recitals 365 to 374 of the regulation at issue, the Commission considered that a downward adjustment to the export price under Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation was warranted.

150. In particular, in recital 373 of that regulation, the Commission considered that, when looking at the whole picture of the Sinopec Group and at the activities of Sinopec Central China, a related company making all the export sales of Sinopec's relevant products to the European Union, Sinopec Central China 'could not be considered as an internal sales department, but rather qualified as a trader within the meaning of Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation'. To reach that conclusion, the Commission took into consideration in its analysis five elements: (81)
– first, Sinopec Central-China was looking for customers and established contact with them;

• second, Sinopec Chongqing, a producer of the relevant products, made direct export sales;
  • third, Sinopec Chongqing and Sinopec Ningxia, another producer of the relevant products, made direct sales in China;
  • fourth, Sinopec Chongqing and Sinopec Ningxia incurred selling costs;
  • fifth, Sinopec Central-China also traded goods made by producers other than Sinopec Chongqing and Sinopec Ningxia.
    • 151. Sinopec challenged the abovementioned conclusion before the General Court.
    • 152. In the judgment under appeal, the General Court, first, rejected the Commission's argument according to which an adjustment under Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation must in principle be made once an undertaking sets up a related company to perform its export sales functions. (82)
    • 153. Second, the General Court agreed with the Commission that, given the existence of common control, it was necessary to ascertain whether the totality of the relevant facts demonstrated the existence of a 'single economic entity' and, therefore, whether the functions carried out by the related trader were similar to those of an internal sales department. Accordingly, the General Court ascertained whether the Commission had adduced sufficient consistent evidence to demonstrate that, notwithstanding the existence of common control, Sinopec Central‑China could not be considered to be acting as an internal sales department, so that it was necessary to make the adjustment at issue. (83)
    • 154. Consequently, the General Court analysed each of the abovementioned five elements. It concluded that the first and fifth elements were not relevant for the purpose of determining whether Sinopec Central-China was an internal sales department or an agent; (84) that the second and third elements did not constitute conclusive evidence that Sinopec Central-China could not be considered to be an internal sales department; (85) and that the fourth element did not change the assessment of the second and third elements. (86)
    • 155. In the light of those considerations, the General Court concluded that the second and third elements were not sufficient to constitute a body of consistent evidence that would demonstrate that the functions of Sinopec Central-China were functions similar to those of an agent acting on a commission basis, or that would preclude recognition of its status as an internal sales department. Therefore, according to the General Court, the Commission had failed to discharge its burden of proof in accordance with the case-law and had committed a manifest error of assessment in finding that Sinopec Central-China was performing functions similar to those of an agent acting on a commission basis. (87)
2. Brief summary of the arguments of the parties
156. The third ground of the Commission's appeal is divided into two limbs.

157. By the first limb, the Commission, supported by Kuraray, challenges paragraphs 65 to 79 of the judgment under appeal. The Commission submits that the General Court committed an error of law in interpreting Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation and disregarded the principle of the burden of proof relating to the adjustment under the relevant case-law. In the present case, the Commission duly discharged its burden of proof. The evidence adduced by the Commission should have shifted the burden of proof on Sinopec in order to let it prove that the adjustment under Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation was not warranted. It follows that paragraphs 69 and 70 of the judgment under appeal are allegedly vitiated by an error of law.

158. By the second limb, the Commission, first, submits that, by analysing separately each of the items of evidence indicated in point 150 of the present Opinion, the General Court made an error of law in applying Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation. Under the case-law, the significance of those elements can only be considered globally and not by taking into account those elements one by one. Those elements can be meaningful only if they are taken into consideration as a whole body of evidence in support of the conclusion put forward in the regulation at issue. The Commission argues that the General Court failed to apply that standard. Second, the Commission challenges the General Court's conclusions relating to each of the five elements mentioned in point 150 of the present Opinion. In particular, as regards the third element, the Commission submits a breach of the duty to state reasons by the General Court.
159. As regards the first limb, Sinopec, supported by Weghochem, disputes the Commission's arguments.

160. As regards the second limb, as a preliminary point, Wegochem argues that it is inadmissible since it is an attempt to contest factual determinations made by the General Court. Sinopec and Wegochem then challenge the Commission's arguments relating to each of the abovementioned five elements.
3. Analysis
(a) The adjustment under Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation

161. Under Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation, an adjustment may be made for differences in commissions paid in respect of the sales under consideration. The second sentence of that provision states that the term 'commissions' is to be
understood to include the mark-up received by a trader of the product or the like product if the functions of such a trader are similar to those of an agent working on a commission basis.

162. The second sentence has been inserted in Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation by Council Regulation (EC) No 1972/2002. (88) It results from recital 6 of that regulation that the rationale of the insertion was to clarify, in line with the consistent practice of the institutions, that such adjustments were also to be made if the parties did not act on the basis of a principal-agent relationship, but achieved the same economic result by acting as buyer and seller. Accordingly, Article 2(10) (i) of the basic Regulation allows an adjustment to be made not only for differences in commissions paid in respect of the sales under consideration, but also for the mark-up received by traders of the product if they carry out functions which are similar to those of an agent working on a commission basis.

163. However, as the General Court rightly observed in paragraph 60 et seq. of the judgment under appeal, it results from the case-law that an adjustment under Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation cannot be made where the producer and its related distributor responsible for exports to the European Union form a single economic entity. (89)

164. In fact, the circumstance that production and sales activities are distributed across legally distinct companies within a group does not alter the fact that the group constitutes a single economic entity. Such a group simply organises its activities internally in a manner that, in other cases, would be carried out by a single legal entity. The economic rationale of recognising a single economic entity is to prevent the artificial exclusion of sales costs from a product's valuation simply because a group uses a separate legal subsidiary rather than an internal sales department. Both corporate structures are economically equivalent. (90)

165. It follows that a distributor that forms a single economic entity with a producer established in a third State cannot be regarded as carrying out functions similar to those of an agent working on a commission basis, within the meaning of Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation. (91)

166. A single economic entity exists where a producer entrusts tasks normally falling within the responsibilities of an internal sales department to a distribution company for its products which it controls economically. (92) Consequently, although the existence of control by the producer over the related trader, or of control common to both of those companies, is a prerequisite for the existence of a single economic entity, such an entity can be found to exist only if the functions carried out by the related trader are similar to those of an internal sales department. (93)

167. The analysis therefore follows a functional approach. What matters is the substance over the form. In the analysis of whether there is a single economic entity between a producer and its related distributor, it is crucial to consider the economic reality of the relationship between that producer and that distributor. In view of the requirement of a conclusion reflecting the economic reality of the relationship between that producer and that distributor, the EU institutions are required to take account of 'all factors relevant' to the determination as to whether or not that distributor carries out the functions of an integrated sales department within that producer. (94)

168. It is in particular necessary to assess the function carried out by the related trader within the group to which it belongs. Accordingly, the Commission should examine the overall functions carried out by that company in the marketing and export of the product concerned as well as of other products, both within the group and in its relations with independent third party producers. (95)

169. The requirement to consider the economic reality of the relationship between the producer and the related distributor points to the consideration of elements such as the level of autonomy of the related distributor, (96) risk allocation, remuneration structure of the related company, exclusivity of the relationship or possibility of representing other unrelated producers. (97)
(b) The first limb of the third ground of appeal

170. By the first limb of the third ground of appeal, the Commission challenges, in essence, paragraphs 69 and 70 of the judgment under appeal. In those paragraphs, the General Court rejected the Commission's argument that a 'general rule' exists requiring in principle an adjustment under Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation once an undertaking sets up a related trading company to perform its export sales functions.

171. However, that assessment made by the General Court contains no error of law and, contrary to what the Commission argues, does not disregard the principle of the burden of proof relating to the adjustment under the relevant case-law.

172. As the General Court rightly pointed out in paragraphs 65 to 68 of the judgment under appeal – and as results from point 84 of the present Opinion – according to consistent case-law, the burden of proof relating to the specific adjustments listed in Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation must be borne by the party who wishes to rely on them. Thus, where the Commission takes the view that it is appropriate to apply a downward adjustment of the export price, on the ground that a sales company affiliated to a producer, in this case Sinopec Central-China, carries out functions similar to those of an agent working on a commission basis, it is the responsibility of that institution to adduce at the very least consistent evidence
showing that that condition is fulfilled. (98)

173. It is only whenever the Commission has adduced consistent evidence to establish that the sales company in question was carrying out functions similar to those of an agent working on a commission basis that said company or its related producer is to adduce evidence that an adjustment under Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation is not justified, for example by demonstrating that they form a single economic entity. (99)

174. It follows, first, that there is no general rule in the case-law mandating an adjustment under Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation simply by reason of the fact that the undertaking sets up a related trading company to perform its export sales functions.

175. The Commission must adduce consistent evidence showing that, despite the existence of control by the producer over the related trader, or of control common to both of those companies, the sales company affiliated to the producer (the related distributor) carries out functions similar to those of an agent working on a commission basis.

176. However, in the present case, the question as to whether the Commission has adduced sufficient evidence to conclude that, despite its status as related distributor, Sinopec Central-China carried out those functions is precisely the issue at stake in the second limb of this ground of appeal.

177. Second, the shift of the burden of proof on Sinopec to which the Commission refers in its appeal, and which is mentioned in point 173 of the present Opinion, will occur only once the Commission has adduced such consistent evidence.
178. It follows that the first limb of the third ground of appeal should be rejected.
(c) The second limb of the third ground of appeal
(1) Admissibility

179. As regards the second limb of the third ground of appeal, it is first necessary to address the plea of inadmissibility raised by Wegochem. As explained in points 22 to 25 of the present Opinion, to which I refer, Wegochem is not entitled to raise such a plea. However, since it raises an issue concerning the Court's jurisdiction, the Court should examine it of its own motion.

180. According to settled case-law, the Court has no jurisdiction to establish the facts or, in principle, to examine the evidence which the General Court accepted in support of those facts. (100) Accordingly, in so far as the second limb of the Commission's third ground of appeal seeks re-examination of the evidence relied on by the General Court in reaching its conclusion that the Commission did not discharge its burden of proof to demonstrate that Sinopec Central-China carried out functions similar to those of an agent acting on a commission basis, the Court does not have jurisdiction to examine such ground of appeal unless that evidence is distorted. (101)

181. However, the issue as to whether the General Court applied the correct standard in the assessment of the evidence is a matter of law, for which the Court has jurisdiction. (102) In the same vein, the issue concerning the relevance of the elements taken into consideration by the Commission in determining whether a related distributor carries out functions which are similar to those of an agent working on a commission basis, or whether a single economic entity exists for the purposes of Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation, are also matters of law that can be examined in an appeal. (103)
(2) Substance
182. On the merits, the Commission contests first of all the standard of assessment of the evidence used by the General Court.

183. On that point I agree with the Commission that, according to the case-law, the five elements mentioned in point 150 of the present Opinion, constituting the body of evidence, should not be assessed as to their individual meaning but should be considered globally as a full body of evidence supporting the conclusion in the regulation at issue.

184. In fact, as results from the case-law mentioned in points 167 and 168 of the present Opinion, determining whether an adjustment under Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation is warranted, or whether it is not because the producer and its related distributor responsible for exports to the European Union form a single economic entity, requires taking account of 'all relevant factors' relating to the economic reality of the relationship between that producer and that distributor.

185. However, in the present case, the General Court did carry out a global assessment of all the factors supporting the Commission's conclusion in the regulation at issue. After analysing each of the five elements individually – in paragraphs 82 to 111 of the judgment under appeal – the General Court reached its final conclusion in paragraph 112, explicitly referring to all of the five elements constituting the body of evidence. The General Court concluded that the only two elements it deemed relevant – namely the second and the third elements – were not sufficient to constitute a body of consistent evidence that would demonstrate that the functions of Sinopec Central-China were functions similar to those of
an agent acting on a commission basis. Accordingly, the Commission's complaint that the General Court applied the wrong standard of assessment should be rejected.

• 186. The Commission then contests the General Court's analysis of each of the five elements mentioned in point 150 above constituting the body of evidence supporting its conclusion in the regulation at issue.
  • 187. In that regard, I note that the General Court's conclusion reached in paragraph 112 of the judgment under appeal, following its global assessment of the evidence, was based only on two of the five elements upon which the Commission had relied in the regulation at issue because the General Court had dismissed two elements (the first and the fifth) as irrelevant, while a third (the fourth element) was found not to alter its assessment of the two remaining elements.
  • 188. Consequently, even if the General Court applied the correct standard of assessment in paragraph 112 of the judgment under appeal, should it be established that its global assessment was based only on a partial set of evidence – due to an error of law in assessing the relevance of certain factors – the entire assessment would be vitiated.
  • 189. As regards the first of the five elements mentioned in point 150 above, namely that Sinopec Central-China was looking for customers and established contact with them, the General Court considered in paragraphs 82 to 84 of the judgment under appeal that it was not relevant. The General Court considered that, since looking for customers and establishing contact with them are activities that may be performed both by an internal sales department and by a sales agent, that element was not relevant for the analysis.
  • 190. The Commission contests that analysis, which, in so far as it relates to the relevance of an element taken into consideration in determining the existence of a single economic entity, concerns a matter of law. (104)
  • 191. As recalled above, (105) in order to determine the existence of a single economic entity it is necessary to examine the overall functions carried out by the related distributor in the marketing and export of the product concerned in the light of the economic reality of its relationship with the producer.
  • 192. In that context, I agree with the General Court that looking for customers and establishing contact with them is an activity that, in the absence of an external sales agent, may be performed by an internal sales department. Therefore, I think that the General Court did not err when it found that the first element is not decisive for establishing whether the related distributor acts as an internal sales department or as a sales agent.
  • 193. However, the fact that an element is not necessarily decisive does not mean that it is irrelevant.
  • 194. The fact that the related distributor looks for customers and establishes contact with them is a relevant factor to understand the overall functions that the related entity carries out in the light of its economic relationship with the producer. Should it be established that the related entity did not look for customers and did not directly establish contact with them, this would be a strong sign that that entity is not carrying out functions which are similar to those of an agent working on a commission basis. In fact, the case-law shows that the General Court considered the fact that a related distributor marketed the products, managed contacts with existing and potential customers, solicited and received the orders and negotiated the sales to be a relevant element to determine whether that entity acted as an agent. (106)
  • 195. Consequently, the General Court erred in law in concluding in paragraph 84 of the judgment under appeal that the first element was irrelevant in determining whether Sinopec Central-China was acting as an agent working on a commission basis, within the meaning of Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation.
  • 196. As regards the second element, listed in point 150 above, concerning the fact that Sinopec Chongqing made direct export sales, the Commission does not contest any specific error of law in the analysis carried out by the General Court in paragraphs 85 to 94 of the judgment under appeal. It submits that the General Court omitted to link the assessment of the direct sales with an analysis of their relevance as to the economic relationship between Sinopec Chongqing and Sinopec Central-China. However, in so far as the Commission is to be understood as requesting a re-evaluation of the assessment of the evidence carried out by the General Court, that request is inadmissible on appeal. In so far as the Commission's complaint is to be understood as being directed against the standard of assessment used by the General Court, that complaint has already been rejected in points 182 to 185 of the present Opinion.
  • 197. As regards the third element listed in point 150 above, the General Court held in paragraphs 97 and 98 of the judgment under appeal that, while the direct domestic sales by Sinopec Chongqing and Sinopec Ningxia proved that they possessed the necessary infrastructure to operate without intermediaries, producers may legitimately utilise different internal departments or related entities for their export operations than they do for their domestic markets. The General Court concluded therefore that the third element was not conclusive evidence that might preclude recognition of Sinopec Central-China's status as an internal sales department.
  • 198. Contrary to what the Commission asserts, I do not see any contradiction in that reasoning. The claim of breach of the duty to state reasons by the General Court cannot therefore be upheld. In so far as the Commission asks the Court to re-
evaluate the assessment of the evidence carried out by the General Court and come to a different conclusion than the one reached in the judgment under appeal, that request is inadmissible on appeal.

199. As to the fourth element listed in paragraph 150 above, namely that Sinopec Chongqing and Sinopec Ningxia incurred selling costs, the General Court, in paragraphs 100 to 102 of the judgment under appeal, linked it to the second and third elements and concluded that it did not change the assessment of those elements.

200. The Commission itself links its complaint against that part of the judgment to the unlawfulness of the analyses relating to the second and third elements. However, it results from the preceding points of the present Opinion that the complaints against the analysis related to the second and third elements must be rejected. Consequently, the Commission's complaint against the General Court's analysis relating to the fourth element also cannot be upheld.

201. As regards, finally, the fifth element listed in point 150 above, concerning the fact that Sinopec Central-China also traded goods made by producers other than Sinopec Chongqing and Sinopec Ningxia, the General Court concluded, in paragraph 111 of the judgment under appeal, that it was of no relevance in demonstrating that Sinopec Central-China was performing functions similar to those of an agent working on a commission basis. The analysis that led to that conclusion is divided into two parts. First, in paragraphs 106 to 108 of that judgment, after having referred to the relevant case-law, the General Court considered that, as the Commission had not carried out an examination of the proportion of Sinopec Central-China's total turnover of the sale of all products purchased from companies other than Sinopec Chongqing and Sinopec Ningxia, it could not rely on the fifth element to argue that no single economic entity was established. Second, in paragraphs 109 and 110 of the judgment under appeal, the General Court held that, in any event, even if the Commission had been entitled to confine itself to examining the turnover of Sinopec Central-China generated by its PVA sales, it was established that the purchases by Sinopec Central-China of PVA produced by unrelated producers represented only 2% of its purchases of PVA from Sinopec Chongqing and Sinopec Ningxia and that the PVA which it purchased from unrelated producers were in any event sold in China to a 'related company'.

202. The Commission contests that analysis, which, just as for the first element, in so far as it relates to the relevance of an element taken into consideration in determining the existence of a single economic entity, concerns a matter of law. (107)

203. As regards the first part of the analysis, on which the General Court relied for its conclusion in paragraph 111 of the judgment under appeal, I observe that the analysis in paragraphs 106 and 107 of that judgment is consistent with the caselaw mentioned therein. However, the conclusion in paragraph 108 of that judgment that the Commission could not use the fifth element at all as a relevant factor because the Commission did not analyse the proportion of the total turnover of the sale of all products purchased from companies other than Sinopec Chongqing and Sinopec Ningxia is in my view erroneous.

204. As recalled above, (108) the case-law entitles the EU institutions to take account of 'all relevant factors' relating to the economic reality of the relationship between the producer and the related distributor to determine whether a single economic entity exists. Consequently, those factors cannot necessarily be limited to the analysis of the proportion of the total turnover of the sales of all products made by the related distributor. The proportion of the sales of the product concerned can also constitute a relevant factor that the EU institutions are entitled to take into account in the analysis. (109) The General Court therefore erred in law in finding in paragraph 111 of the judgment under appeal that the fifth element was irrelevant because the Commission did not carry out an analysis of the proportion of the total turnover of the sales of all products made by Sinopec Central-China.

205. As regards the second part of the analysis, contained in paragraphs 109 and 110 of the judgment under appeal, the General Court carried it out 'in any event' and therefore as an obiter dictum. In those paragraphs, although it did not state it expressly, the General Court seems to have concluded, in essence, that, on the basis of the analysis of the very limited proportion of turnover relating (only) to the product concerned generated by Sinopec Central-China from other unrelated producers (considered by the Commission), the fifth element did not constitute sufficient evidence to consider that that company was performing functions similar to those of an agent working on a commission basis.

206. However, it must be observed that that (implicit) conclusion concerning the fifth element is not mentioned at all in paragraph 112 of the judgment under appeal, in which the General Court carries out its global assessment of the five elements. Therefore, the General Court did not take into account at all the fifth element as evidence in that global assessment, given that it (erroneously) considered such an element to be irrelevant.

207. In conclusion, I consider that General Court committed two errors of law by considering that the first and the fifth element were irrelevant in the analysis to determine whether Sinopec Central-China, despite its status of related company, was performing functions similar to those of an agent working on a commission basis.

208. Consequently, since the global assessment of the evidence that the General Court carried out in paragraph 112 of the judgment under appeal was based only on the second and third elements because the General Court erroneously dismissed the first and the fifth as irrelevant, it must be concluded that that global assessment is vitiated by errors of law.
209. Accordingly, I propose that the Court should uphold the second limb of the third ground of the Commission's appeal.
III. The cross-appeal

• 210. Sinopec's cross-appeal concerns paragraphs 141 to 159 of the judgment under appeal. In those paragraphs, the General Court rejected the plea by which Sinopec contested the Commission's decision to adjust upwards the normal value under Article 2(10)(b) of the basic Regulation to reflect the difference between the valued added tax (VAT) rate payable and the VAT refund rate upon exportation.
  • 211. By its cross-appeal, Sinopec asks the Court to set aside the judgment under appeal in so far as it upheld the adjustment to the normal value for non-recoverable VAT, to annul the regulation at issue in so far as it made that adjustment and to order the Commission to pay the costs; alternatively, Sinopec asks the Court to refer the case back to the General Court and to reserve the costs.
  • 212. The Commission, supported by Kuraray, asks the Court to dismiss the cross-appeal and order Sinopec to pay the costs. Kuraray also asks the Court to declare the cross-appeal inadmissible.
  • 213. In support of its cross-appeal, Sinopec relies on four grounds of appeal.
  • 214. In paragraphs 141 to 159 of the judgment under appeal, the General Court upheld the Commission's decision, as set out in recitals 387 and 388 of the regulation at issue, to adjust the constructed normal value to account for non-refundable VAT included in the export price. The General Court found that, although the wording of the regulation at issue was not easy to understand, read in context and supported by evidence in the administrative file, the Commission had sufficiently demonstrated, first, that the export price included non-refundable VAT, whereas the normal value had been constructed using representative country data under Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation net of VAT, and, second, that, consequently, that asymmetry justified an upward adjustment of the normal value to ensure a fair comparison between that value and the export price. (110)
  • 215. However, the General Court held that the Commission had erred in relying on Article 2(10)(b) of the basic Regulation as the legal basis for that adjustment, since that provision does not expressly cover constructed normal values based on representative country data. The General Court found that that error was nevertheless not decisive, as Article 2(10)(k) of the basic Regulation allowed the Commission to adjust for other factors affecting price comparability, including non-refundable VAT. (111)
A. Admissibility and effectiveness of the cross-appeal

• 216. First, Kuraray submits that the cross-appeal is inadmissible in its entirety. According to Kuraray, Sinopec has neither explained nor demonstrated what advantage the cross-appeal would procure to it.
  • 217. By its plea of inadmissibility, Kuraray contests, in essence, Sinopec's interest in bringing the cross-appeal. In accordance with settled case-law, for an appellant to have an interest in bringing proceedings the appeal must be capable, if successful, of procuring an advantage to the party bringing it. Moreover, the Court may of its own motion raise the objection that a party has no interest in bringing or in maintaining an appeal. (112)
  • 218. As explained in points 22 to 25 of the present Opinion, since Kuraray is an intervener, it is not entitled to raise such a plea of inadmissibility. Nonetheless, since that plea raises an issue concerning the Court's jurisdiction, the Court should examine it of its own motion.
  • 219. In my view, there is no doubt that Sinopec has an interest in bringing the cross-appeal. If the cross-appeal is upheld and the Court were to rule that the General Court erred in considering that an adjustment pursuant to Article 2(10)(k) of the basic Regulation could be made, the normal value used to determine Sinopec's dumping margin would be lowered, as would, consequently, its anti-dumping duty. This would undoubtedly constitute an advantage for Sinopec.
  • 220. Second, without raising a plea of inadmissibility, the Commission considers that, due to the lack of a cross-appeal against paragraphs 160 to 164 of the judgment under appeal, the cross-appeal is ineffective in its entirety. In particular, Sinopec did not contest paragraph 160 of said judgment, in which the General Court, by using the word 'necessary', allegedly confirmed the need for an adjustment. That paragraph therefore contradicts Sinopec's arguments raised in the cross-appeal.
  • 221. Paragraph 160 of the judgment under appeal constitutes merely a summary of Sinopec's arguments raised in its second complaint of the third part of the second plea at first instance. It is not a finding of the General Court. The lack of a specific challenge to that paragraph in no way impacts the effectiveness of the cross-appeal.
B. The first ground of appeal

222. By the first ground of its cross-appeal, Sinopec submits that by changing, in the judgment under appeal, the legal basis for the adjustment for non-recoverable VAT from Article 2(10)(b) to Article 2(10)(k) of the basic Regulation, the General Court misinterpreted the chapeau of Article 2(10) as well as Article 2(10)(k) of that regulation.

• 223. Sinopec submits that, in the present case, the Commission did not demonstrate that the conditions set out in Article 2(10)(k) of the basic Regulation were met, since it did not apply that provision in the regulation at issue, but Article 2(10)(b) of the basic Regulation. It was not for the General Court, but for the Commission to make the adjustment on the basis of Article 2(10)(k) of the basic Regulation and to prove that the conditions for applying that provision were met. The General Court's role is limited to examining the legality of acts by the Commission and not to correct legal errors committed by that institution. The General Court's improper substitution of the legal basis allowed the adjustment to stand despite the Commission's failure to meet its burden of proof.
  • 224. The Commission, supported by Kuraray, disputes Sinopec's arguments.
  • 225. In paragraphs 153 to 156 of the judgment under appeal, the General Court held that the Commission had found that the export price included an amount corresponding to the non-refundable VAT, whereas the normal value had been constructed net of VAT and that, consequently, that asymmetry warranted an upward adjustment of the normal value to ensure a fair comparison between the normal value and the export price.
  • 226. Sinopec does not contest those paragraphs of the judgment under appeal and the findings contained therein. In particular, Sinopec does not contest the necessity to make an upward adjustment of the normal value to ensure a fair comparison under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation, given the aforementioned asymmetry, which undoubtedly affected price comparability.
  • 227. In paragraph 157 of the judgment under appeal, the General Court found that the Commission had committed an error of law by considering that the legal basis for the upward adjustment of the normal value was Article 2(10)(b) of the basic Regulation. The General Court ruled, however, that that error did not justify the annulment of the regulation at issue since it had no decisive effect on the Commission's assessment, given that the conditions of application of Article 2(10)(k) of the basic Regulation were in any case satisfied. It is the 'substitution of the legal basis' for the adjustment, as Sinopec describes it, that is contested in this ground of appeal.
  • 228. However, the General Court's finding in paragraph 157 of the judgment under appeal contains, in my opinion, no error of law.
  • 229. First, the General Court did not commit any error in finding that the conditions for the application of Article 2(10)(k) of the basic Regulation were satisfied.
  • 230. According to said provision 'an adjustment may … be made for differences in other factors not provided for under [Article 2(10)(a) to (j) of the basic Regulation], if it is demonstrated that they affect price comparability …, in particular if customers consistently pay different prices on the domestic market because of the difference in such factors'.
  • 231. That provision constitutes a residual 'catch-all' provision which was introduced in EU anti-dumping law (113) in order to allow for adjustments for 'other factors' not specifically listed in points (a) to (j) of Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation and, thus, to eliminate the exclusive nature of that provision in relation to allowances. (114)
  • 232. As I noted in points 225 and 226 of the present Opinion, it is undisputed that the inclusion in the export price of an amount corresponding to the non-refundable VAT, and the construction of the normal value net of VAT constituted a difference in factors affecting prices and price comparability which warranted an upward adjustment of the normal value under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation in order to ensure a fair comparison. Accordingly, the condition set forth in the first sentence of that provision is satisfied.
  • 233. Regarding the second sub-clause of Article 2(10)(k) of the basic Regulation which states 'in particular if customers consistently pay different prices on the domestic market because of the difference in such factors' – the use of the word 'in particular' indicates that it does not impose an additional requirement. Instead, it aims at illustrating a situation where the condition – namely that it is demonstrated that the factor in question affects price comparability – has been satisfied.
  • 234. Consequently, given that the General Court found that it had been demonstrated that the asymmetry relating to the VAT between the constructed normal value and the export price affected price comparability, it committed no error in concluding that the conditions for the application of Article 2(10)(k) of the basic Regulation were satisfied.
  • 235. Second, in a situation where it is established that an adjustment was necessary to ensure a fair comparison under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation and that the conditions of Article 2(10)(k) of the same regulation were satisfied, the Commission's error of law in classifying the adjustment under Article 2(10)(b) of that regulation was purely formal in nature. In fact, that error in the legal classification of the adjustment had no decisive influence on either the Commission's assessment that the adjustment was necessary or on the amount of the adjustment and the resulting dumping margin. As rightly held by the General Court, an error of purely formal significance, particularly concerning the legal basis, cannot lead to the annulment of the EU act at issue. (115)
  • 236. Third, as regards the alleged overstepping by the General Court of its role, which is limited to examining the legality of

the Commission's acts, I do not think that the General Court exceeded its powers of review by substituting its own assessment for that of the Commission. In fact, to reach its conclusion, the General Court relied on factors forming an integral part of the Commission's reasoning set out in the regulation at issue and the result of its assessment is consistent with the operative part of this act. (116) The General Court did not make a new assessment of the facts replacing that made by the Commission and, thus, it did not encroach on the broad discretion of that institution in the field of commercial policy – a discretion justified by the complexity of economic, political and legal situations the Commission is required to examine. (117)
237. In the light of the foregoing considerations, I propose that the Court reject the first ground of Sinopec's cross-appeal as unfounded.
C. The second ground of appeal

238. The second ground of Sinopec's cross-appeal is directed against paragraph 158 of the judgment under appeal. Sinopec submits that by stating that the constructed normal value 'replaces' the price of the product concerned on the domestic market of the exporting country, the General Court misinterpreted Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation. According to Sinopec, while a constructed normal value under the methodology of Article 2(3) to (6) of the basic Regulation is intended to provide a proxy for the domestic sale price, that is not the case for Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation, which instructs the Commission to completely disregard domestic sales. However, according to Sinopec, demonstrating that 'customers consistently pay different prices on the domestic market because of the difference in such factors' is a necessary condition in order to make an adjustment under Article 2(10)(k) of the basic Regulation.

239. The Commission, supported by Kuraray, disputes Sinopec's arguments. Kuraray additionally submits that the second ground of appeal is inadmissible because it is not sufficiently clear and precise to enable the Court to carry out its review. Consequently, according to Kuraray, it fails to meet the standards under Article 169(2) of the Rules of procedure of the Court of Justice.

240. As regards, first of all, the admissibility of the second ground of appeal, I consider that, even supposing that the Court should analyse of its own motion the plea of inadmissibility submitted by Kuraray, which, as an intervener, as results from points 22 to 25 of the present Opinion, is not entitled to raise such a plea, this ground of appeal is not inadmissible. In fact, this ground of appeal indicates precisely the contested elements of the judgment which Sinopec seeks to have set aside (namely paragraph 158 of the judgment under appeal) as well as the legal arguments specifically put forward in support of the ground of appeal (namely the alleged infringement of Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation). (118)

241. However, in my opinion, this ground of appeal is ineffective. As I noted in point 233 of the present Opinion, the second sub-clause of Article 2(10)(k) of the basic Regulation does not impose an additional requirement. It highlights instead a specific situation in which the condition set forth in the first sub-clause – namely that it is demonstrated that the difference in factors at issue affects price comparability – is met. In paragraphs 153 to 157 of the judgment under appeal, the General Court established that since that condition was met the Commission was allowed to make the upward adjustment of the normal value. Therefore, even if, as Sinopec argues, paragraph 158 of that judgment were erroneous with regard to the interpretation of Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation in conjunction with the second sub-clause of Article 2(10)(k) of that regulation, such an error would not call into question the conclusion that the adjustment was warranted in the present case.

242. In any case, the second ground of appeal is also based on an erroneous reading of the judgment under appeal. In fact, by stating in paragraph 128 of the judgment under appeal that the constructed normal value 'replaces' the price of the product concerned on the domestic market of the exporting country, the General Court did not mean, as Sinopec's argument suggests, that the Commission should take domestic sales into account when constructing the normal value. The General Court rather meant that the constructed normal value under Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation replaces, in the fair comparison between the normal value and the export price, the normal value as defined under Article 2(1) of the basic Regulation.
243. Consequently, I propose that the Court also reject the second ground of Sinopec's cross-appeal.
D. The third ground of appeal

244. By the third ground of its cross-appeal, Sinopec submits that the General Court distorted the evidence before it by failing to assess the relevance of a decision of the US Court of International Trade (United States), which confirmed that adjustments for non-recoverable VAT are illegal not only in the context of a fair comparison, but also when the normal value is constructed. According to Sinopec, by not making any reference to that decision in the judgment under appeal and consequently by failing to address its relevance, the General Court distorted the evidence. Sinopec argues that that distortion affects the conclusion set out in paragraph 156 of the judgment under appeal that the Commission had demonstrated the need for an adjustment for non-recoverable VAT.
245. The Commission, supported by Kuraray, disputes Sinopec's arguments. Kuraray also submits that the third ground of

appeal is inadmissible because Sinopec did not provide any element to support the alleged distortion of the evidence. Consequently, according to Kuraray, this ground of appeal fails to meet the standards under Article 169(2) of the Rules of Procedure of the Court of Justice.

246. Again, as regards, first of all, Kuraray's plea of inadmissibility, I consider that, even assuming that the Court should analyse of its own motion that plea, which Kuraray, as an intervener, is not entitled to raise, (119) the third ground of appeal is not inadmissible. Similarly to the previous ground of appeal, the third ground of appeal indicates precisely the contested elements of the judgment which Sinopec seeks to have set aside (namely paragraph 156 of the judgment under appeal) as well as the legal arguments specifically advanced in support of that ground of appeal (namely the alleged distortion of evidence by not considering the abovementioned decision of the US Court of International Trade).
247. However, in my view, the third ground of appeal should be rejected on the merits.

248. First, I agree with Commission that the consistency of the practice of EU institutions with the approach of the US authorities is not relevant. The decision of the US Court of International Trade is an example of a practice in another jurisdiction that may inspire a certain interpretation of EU anti-dumping law, but cannot be qualified as 'evidence'. Therefore, since there is no evidence there cannot be any 'distortion of the evidence'.

249. Second, and in any case, the failure to assess evidence cannot lead to a distortion of that evidence. According to the case-law, a complaint of distortion of the evidence requires the appellant not only to indicate precisely the evidence alleged to have been distorted by the General Court, but also to show the errors of appraisal which, in its view, led to such distortion. (120)

250. It follows that a distortion of the evidence presupposes that the evidence has been assessed in a manner manifestly contrary to its content. Sinopec, however, does not claim that the General Court distorted the assessment of the decision of the US Court of International Trade, which it submitted before that Court. It contends, rather, that the General Court did not take that evidence into account at all in its assessment. That claim essentially amounts to a complaint of failure to state reasons.

251. However, even if Sinopec's claim should be understood in that way, it should nevertheless also be rejected. The absence of a reference in the judgment under appeal to the decision of the US Court of International Trade at issue necessarily implies that the General Court regarded such decision as irrelevant. That lack of a reference in that judgment does not in any case preclude Sinopec from raising complaints against the judgment under appeal or the Court from examining those complaints.
252. Consequently, I propose that the Court also reject the third ground of Sinopec's cross-appeal.
E. The fourth ground of appeal

253. By the fourth ground of its cross-appeal, Sinopec challenges paragraphs 150 to 156 of the judgment under appeal. It alleges a breach of the right to be heard and of the obligation to state reasons.

254. First, Sinopec submits that, since the legal basis for the adjustment for non-recoverable VAT was changed from Article 2(10)(b) to Article 2(10)(k) of the basic Regulation, Sinopec was prevented from providing evidence that the conditions of that latter provision were not met. Sinopec recognises having had the opportunity to argue before the General Court whether the conditions of Article 2(10)(k) of the basic Regulation were met. However, the right to be heard before the Commission, the author of the act, is distinct from the possibility to be heard before the General Court. Sinopec argues that if it had had the chance to present its arguments, specifically on the condition set forth in the second sub-clause of Article 2(10)(k) of the basic Regulation, the Commission may have taken a different decision.

255. Second, Sinopec submits that, despite its requests, the Commission did not explain why the adjustment at issue was necessary when the normal value is based on information from a third State. It was only during the proceedings before the General Court that the Commission provided an explanation. However, allowing the Commission only to provide explanations during legal proceedings before the EU Courts as to why it took a certain approach, particularly if such an explanation was explicitly requested during the administrative procedure, and where the EU Courts found that the Commission committed an error of law, risks rendering the obligation to state reasons and the right to be heard of the interested parties meaningless.
256. The Commission, supported by Kuraray, disputes Sinopec's arguments.

257. As regards, first, the alleged violation of the right to be heard, I observe that Sinopec's argument focuses on the condition set forth in the second sub-clause of Article 2(10)(k) of the basic Regulation. However, as I noted in points 232 and 241 of the present Opinion, the second sub-clause of that provision does not impose an additional requirement, but merely highlights a specific situation in which the condition set forth in the first sub-clause is satisfied. Thus, in such a situation in which the condition mentioned in the first sub-clause is met and therefore the adjustment is warranted, even if it was true

that Sinopec did not have the possibility of presenting its arguments on the condition set forth in the second sub-clause, this would not have any impact on the adjustment at issue. This ground of appeal is therefore in my view ineffective.

258. In any case, according to settled case-law, although an applicant cannot be required to show that the Commission's decision would have been different in the absence of the procedural irregularity in question, but simply that such a possibility cannot be totally ruled out, since that party would have been better able to defend itself had there been no irregularity, the fact remains that the existence of an irregularity relating to the rights of the defence can result in the annulment of the measure in question only where there is a possibility that, due to that irregularity, the administrative procedure could have resulted in a different outcome and thus in fact adversely affected the rights of the defence. (121)

259. However, in the present case, Sinopec did not produce any element that would show that in a situation in which, as observed in paragraphs 225 and 226 of the present Opinion, the adjustment was warranted, the administrative procedure could have resulted in a different outcome.

260. As regards the second limb of the fourth ground of appeal, the General Court rightly found in paragraph 152 of the judgment under appeal that, according to the case-law of the Court of Justice, 'a regulation imposing anti-dumping duties must contain the essential part of the Commission's reasoning, but need not include specific reasons for each of the numerous factual arguments relied on by the interested parties' and that 'the Court may therefore ask the Commission for additional explanations and take them into account when carrying out its review, provided that they are based on material in the Commission's file'.

261. Sinopec does not challenge that case-law, nor does it contest that the additional explanations provided by the Commission were based on material existing in the Commission's file. Against that background, the second limb of this ground of appeal also cannot succeed.
262. In the light of the foregoing considerations, I propose that the Court also reject the fourth ground of Sinopec's crossappeal and, consequently, this cross-appeal in its entirety.
IV. The action before the General Court

263. In accordance with Article 61(1) of the Statute of the Court of Justice of the European Union, if the Court quashes the decision of the General Court, it may itself give final judgment in the matter, where the state of the proceedings so permits.

264. I consider that this is the case, first, with regard to the second complaint of the third plea raised by Sinopec before the General Court, relating to the alleged punitive nature of the source of the facts available. In fact, it results from points 35 to 46 of the present Opinion that the Commission did not commit any manifest error of assessment in recitals 329 and 333 of the regulation at issue by constructing the normal value for Sinopec Ningxia in accordance with Article 2(6a) of the basic Regulation, using information provided by the other cooperating exporting producers under Article 18 of the same regulation and, in particular, for each product type reported by that company, using the highest normal value of the other cooperating exporting producers. The abovementioned second complaint of the third plea raised by Sinopec should therefore be rejected in its entirety.

265. Second, I consider that the Court may also give final judgment both on the first and second parts of the second plea raised by Sinopec before the General Court, alleging infringement of Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation.

266. As regards the complaint alleging infringement of the obligation to make a fair comparison at the same level of trade, under Article 2(10) of the basic Regulation, between the export price and the constructed normal value under Article 2(6a) of that regulation, in relation to 'the costs at issue', it results from points 64 to 146 of the present Opinion that the Commission did not commit any manifest error of assessment in that regard in the regulation at issue. That complaint – contained in the second part of the second plea raised at first instance – must therefore be dismissed.

267. As regards the complaint alleging infringement of Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation, it results from points 161 to 169 as well as 184 of the present Opinion that, in order to determine whether an adjustment under Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation is warranted because the related trader carries out functions that are similar to those of an agent working on a commission basis, or whether it is not warranted because the producer and its related distributor responsible for exports to the European Union form a single economic entity, it is necessary to take account of 'all relevant factors' relating to the economic reality of the relationship between that producer and that distributor.

268. In the present case it is therefore necessary to analyse the five elements listed in point 150 of the present Opinion which constitute the body of evidence supporting the Commission's conclusion in the regulation at issue that the adjustment was warranted. It is necessary to verify whether the Commission adduced, at the very least, consistent evidence showing that the conditions for the application of the adjustment were fulfilled. (122)

269. As regards the first element, namely that Sinopec Central-China was looking for customers and established contact with them, it results from points 189 to 194 of the present Opinion that that activity is relevant to determining that a related

entity is carrying out functions which are similar to those of an agent working on a commission basis, but is not decisive to assess whether the related distributor acts as an internal sales department or as a sales agent.

270. As regards the second element, concerning the fact that Sinopec Chongqing made direct export sales to the Unites States, I refer to the analysis contained in paragraphs 88 to 93 of the judgment under appeal that applies correctly the relevant case-law. Accordingly, that element is relevant to the analysis but, in the light of the limited comparative amount of the sales and the specificities of the present case, such an element does not constitute in itself conclusive evidence that the conditions for the application of the adjustment under Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation are fulfilled.

271. As regards the third element, namely that Sinopec Chongqing and Sinopec Ningxia made direct sales in China, I refer to the analysis contained in paragraphs 95 to 99 of the judgment under appeal that applies correctly the relevant case-law. Accordingly, although that element is also relevant to the analysis, it does not constitute in itself conclusive evidence that the conditions for the application of the adjustment under Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation are fulfilled.

272. The same is true as regards the fourth element listed in point 150 of the present Opinion, concerning the fact that Sinopec Chongqing and Sinopec Ningxia incurred selling costs. Since it is not disputed that Sinopec Chongqing and Sinopec Ningxia incurred costs only in relation to sales on the domestic Chinese market and, in the case of Sinopec Chongqing, direct export sales to the United States, the existence of those selling costs is linked respectively to the second and third element.

273. Finally, as regards the fifth element, concerning the fact that Sinopec Central-China also traded goods made by producers other than Sinopec Chongqing and Sinopec Ningxia, it is established that there is no data on the file concerning the proportion of the total turnover of the sales of all products purchased from companies other than Sinopec Chongqing and Sinopec Ningxia. It is, however, apparent from the file that the purchases by Sinopec Central-China of PVA produced by unrelated producers represented only 2% of its PVA purchases from Sinopec Chongqing and Sinopec Ningxia. Thus, the turnover of Sinopec Central-China generated by its PVA sales came from PVA almost all of which it had purchased from Sinopec Chongqing and Sinopec Ningxia. Furthermore, it is also undisputed that the PVA which Sinopec Central-China purchased from unrelated producers were not exported into the European Union but were sold, in China, to a related company and therefore constituted intragroup transactions. Against that background, while the fact that the related trader sells goods from producers other than the related producer is an important element to be taken into consideration in the analysis, under the specific circumstances of the present case, it must be concluded that the fifth element does not constitute sufficient evidence to consider that that related trader was performing functions similar to those of an agent working on a commission basis.

274. In the light of all of the foregoing considerations in relation to the first to fifth elements, I consider that, under the specific circumstances of this case, those elements taken together do not constitute a sufficient body of consistent evidence that would demonstrate that Sinopec Central-China carried out functions similar to those of an agent acting on a commission basis. In those circumstances, it must be concluded that the Commission has not discharged its burden of proof that the conditions for the application of an adjustment under Article 2(10)(i) of the basic Regulation were met. Consequently, the first part of the second plea in law raised by Sinopec must be upheld.
V. The costs

275. Under Article 184(2) of the Rules of Procedure of the Court of Justice, where the appeal is well founded and the Court itself gives final judgment in the case, the Court is to make a decision as to the costs. Under Article 138(1) and (3) of those rules, which apply to the procedure on appeal pursuant to Article 184(1) of those rules, the unsuccessful party is to be ordered to pay the costs if they have been applied for in the successful party's pleadings and where each party succeeds on some and fails on other heads, the parties shall bear their own costs. However, if it appears justified in the circumstances of the case, the Court may order that one party, in addition to bearing its own costs, pay a proportion of the costs of the other party. Under Article 140(3) of those rules, which apply to the procedure on appeal pursuant to Article 184(1) of the same rules, the Court may order an intervener to bear its own costs.

276. If the Court agrees with my assessment concerning the Commission's appeal and Sinopec's cross-appeal, Sinopec will be the unsuccessful party. In those circumstances, since the Commission and Kuraray have claimed that Sinopec should be ordered to pay the costs, I propose that the Court order Sinopec to pay the costs incurred by the Commission and Kuraray in the appeal and in the cross-appeal.

277. However, in the final judgment on the action at first instance that I propose, Sinopec is successful concerning one of the three pleas in law submitted at first instance that constituted the object of the appeal, while the action is dismissed as to the remainder, including the plea that constituted the object of the cross-appeal. Since the Commission has claimed that Sinopec should be ordered to pay the costs at first instance, I propose that the Court order Sinopec to bear 75% of its own costs at first instance and to pay 75% of the costs incurred by the Commission at first instance and order the Commission to bear 25% of its own costs at first instance and to pay 25% of the costs incurred by Sinopec at first instance.
VI. Conclusion
278. In the light of the foregoing considerations, I propose that the Court should:

• set aside the judgment of the General Court of the European Union of of 21 February 2024, Sinopec Chongqing SVW Chemical and Others v Commission (T‑762/20, EU:T:2024:113), in so far as it annuls Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2020/1336 of 25 September 2020 imposing definitive anti-dumping duties on imports of certain polyvinyl alcohols originating in the People's Republic of China with regard to Sinopec Chongqing SVW Chemical Co. Ltd, Sinopec Great Wall Energy & Chemical (Ningxia) Co. Ltd and Central-China Company, Sinopec Chemical Commercial Holding Co. Ltd. In calculating the rate of the antidumping duty affecting imports into the European Union of polyvinyl alcohols manufactured and sold by them, the European Commission made downward adjustments to the export price under Article 2(10)(e), (g), (i) and (k) of Regulation (EU) 2016/1036 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 8 June 2016 on protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the European Union;
  • annul Implementing Regulation 2020/1336 with regard to Sinopec Chongqing SVW Chemical Co. Ltd, Sinopec Great Wall Energy & Chemical (Ningxia) Co. Ltd and Central-China Company, Sinopec Chemical Commercial Holding Co. Ltd, in so far as, in calculating the rate of the anti-dumping duty affecting imports into the European Union of polyvinyl alcohols manufactured and sold by them, the Commission made downward adjustments to the export price under Article 2(10)(i) of Regulation 2016/1036;
  • dismiss the action at first instance as to the remainder;
  • dismiss the cross-appeal of Sinopec Chongqing SVW Chemical Co. Ltd, Sinopec Great Wall Energy & Chemical (Ningxia) Co. Ltd and Central-China Company, Sinopec Chemical Commercial Holding Co. Ltd;
  • order Sinopec Chongqing SVW Chemical Co. Ltd, Sinopec Great Wall Energy & Chemical (Ningxia) Co. Ltd and Central-China Company, Sinopec Chemical Commercial Holding Co. Ltd to pay the costs incurred by the Commission and Kuraray Europe GmbH relating to the appeal and the cross-appeal;
  • order Sinopec Chongqing SVW Chemical Co. Ltd, Sinopec Great Wall Energy & Chemical (Ningxia) Co. Ltd and Central-China Company, Sinopec Chemical Commercial Holding Co. Ltd to bear 75% of their own costs at first instance and to pay 75% of the costs incurred by the Commission at first instance and order the Commission to bear 25% of its own costs at first instance and to pay 25% of the costs incurred by those companies at first instance;
  • order Wegochem Europe BV to bear its own costs;
  • order Kuraray Europe GmbH to bear its own costs at first instance.

Internal departments typically follow strict corporate protocols. They have no power to negotiate prices outside a narrow range and use the producer's internal systems, while external agents typically enjoy more commercial autonomy to set local sales prices and marketing strategies and operate with a mandate rather than on a direct reporting line. Internal departments work exclusively for the related group and cannot represent other producers while external agents can represent multiple producers and typically have their own client portfolio.
